\u003cdc:date\u003e\u003c![CDATA[2026-02-11]]\u003e\u003c/dc:date\u003e"," \u003c/item\u003e"," \u003citem\u003e"," \u003ctitle\u003e\u003c![CDATA[Kyndryl replaces financial leadership, cites weak reporting controls]]\u003e\u003c/title\u003e"," \u003clink\u003e\u003c![CDATA[https://www.cio.com/article/4130790/kyndryl-replaces-financial-leadership-cites-weak-reporting-controls.html]]\u003e\u003c/link\u003e"," \u003cguid isPermaLink=\"true\"\u003e\u003c![CDATA[https://www.cio.com/article/4130790/kyndryl-replaces-financial-leadership-cites-weak-reporting-controls.html]]\u003e\u003c/guid\u003e"," \u003cdescription\u003e\u003c![CDATA[\u003cdiv id=\"remove_no_follow\"\u003e \u003cdiv class=\"grid grid--cols-10@md grid--cols-8@lg article-column\"\u003e \u003cdiv class=\"col-12 col-10@md col-6@lg col-start-3@lg\"\u003e \u003cdiv class=\"article-column__content\"\u003e","\u003csection class=\"wp-block-bigbite-multi-title\"\u003e\u003cdiv class=\"container\"\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003c/section\u003e \u003cp\u003eKyndryl has replaced its CFO, corporate controller, and general counsel, the company’s CEO Martin Schroeter announced during a conference call to discuss the company’s financial results on Monday.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eIt reported the departures of CFO David Wyshner and General Counsel Edward Sebold to the US Securities and Exchange Commission in an 8-K “Report of unscheduled material events or corporate event.”\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eFormer COO \u003ca href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/harsh-chugh-3788593/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eHarsh Chugh\u003c/a\u003e was named as interim CFO, and deputy general counsel Mark Ringes as interim general counsel in \u003ca href=\"https://investors.kyndryl.com/static-files/c2979bf3-1a6d-4c43-9349-b993cc70da15\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eKyndryl’s Feb. 9 filing with the SEC\u003c/a\u003e. Chugh and Ringes were long-time IBM employees prior to \u003ca href=\"https://www.cio.com/article/189224/what-is-kyndryl-ibms-managed-infrastructure-services-spin-off-explained.html\"\u003eKyndryl’s spin-out in 2021\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eThe filing also named Bhavna Doegar as interim corporate controller, after global controller Vineet Khurana stepped down to take on the role of SVP, business operations. Doegar joined Kyndryl as SVP, finance and strategy, just two months ago, after holding a series of senior roles at Genpact.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eWhile Kyndryl’s 8-K gave no reasons for the execs’ departures, a separate filing on Monday provided some clues, as the company said it was forced to delay filing its audited quarterly results.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eKyndryl “is reviewing its cash management practices, related disclosures (including regarding the drivers of the company’s adjusted free cash flow metric), the efficacy of the company’s internal control over financial reporting, and certain other matters,” it said.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eWhen it does get around to filing its report for the quarter ended December 31, Kyndryl said, it anticipates reporting material weaknesses in its internal control over financial reporting for the full fiscal year ended march 31, and for the three subsequent quarters. These weaknesses “are expected to include, but may not be limited to, the effectiveness and strength of certain functions at the company, including with respect to controls related to information and communication and tone at the top.”\u003c/p\u003e \u003ch2 class=\"wp-block-heading\" id=\"cooperating-with-the-sec\"\u003eCooperating with the SEC\u003c/h2\u003e \u003cp\u003eThe delay followed its receipt of requests for documentation requests from the SEC’s Division of Enforcement.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003e“Due to this review, the finalization of the quarterly report, including the company’s assessment of internal control over financial reporting, requires additional time to complete,” it said, noting that it anticipated no impact on its consolidated balance sheets, or consolidated statements of income cash flows, or equity.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eKyndryl is cooperating with the SEC, Schroeter said during the conference call.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eDespite the anticipated delay in its formal filing with the SEC, the company presented results for the three months ending December 31, 2025, the third quarter of its 2026 fiscal year.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eIt reported revenue for the quarter of $3.9 billion, up 3% year on year, or flat at constant currency rates. Net income was $57 million, down from $215 million a year prior, when the company recorded what it described as “a significant transaction-related benefit” from the sale of Canadian business unit Securities Industry Services (SIS).\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eIt’s been four years since Kyndryl split from IBM, but their relationship continues to weigh heavily on Kyndryl’s performance. “At the time of the spin-off, the commercial agreement that we inherited essentially put 40% of our revenue in a low- to no-margin position,” Schroeter said during the conference call. The company was spending $4 billion a year with IBM on services it then rebilled to its customers. Now that annual spend is down to $2 billon, but the sales relationship with IBM continues to drag Kyndryl’s annual growth down by around 3.5 percentage points, he said.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eKyndryl expects a year-on-year decline in revenue at constant currency of between 2% and 3% for its full fiscal year ending March 31, 2026, interim CFO Harsh Chugh said during the same conference call.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eSchroeter blamed the forecast revenue decline on a number of factors, including headwinds from the evolving IBM relationship and customer concerns around AI and digital sovereignty. “AI is making customers rethink how their infrastructure should run, and the sovereignty discussions around the world are top of mind for everybody,” he said.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eHowever, Schroeter said, “We are growing the core part that matters so much to us,” he said, referring to consulting and hyperscaler-related revenue, which for the most recent quarter rose 29% and 73% year on year respectively.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eAn earlier version of this article misstated the date of one of Kyndryl’s SEC filings.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e","\u003c/div\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003c/div\u003e]]\u003e\u003c/description\u003e"," \u003cpubDate\u003e\u003c![CDATA[Wed, 11 Feb 2026 00:00:00 GMT]]\u003e\u003c/pubDate\u003e"," \u003cdc:date\u003e\u003c![CDATA[2026-02-11]]\u003e\u003c/dc:date\u003e"," \u003c/item\u003e"," \u003citem\u003e"," \u003ctitle\u003e\u003c![CDATA[Your dev team isn’t a cost center — it’s about to become a multiplier]]\u003e\u003c/title\u003e"," \u003clink\u003e\u003c![CDATA[https://www.cio.com/article/4130291/your-dev-team-isnt-a-cost-center-its-about-to-become-a-multiplier.html]]\u003e\u003c/link\u003e"," \u003cguid isPermaLink=\"true\"\u003e\u003c![CDATA[https://www.cio.com/article/4130291/your-dev-team-isnt-a-cost-center-its-about-to-become-a-multiplier.html]]\u003e\u003c/guid\u003e"," \u003cdescription\u003e\u003c![CDATA[\u003cdiv id=\"remove_no_follow\"\u003e \u003cdiv class=\"grid grid--cols-10@md grid--cols-8@lg article-column\"\u003e \u003cdiv class=\"col-12 col-10@md col-6@lg col-start-3@lg\"\u003e \u003cdiv class=\"article-column__content\"\u003e","\u003csection class=\"wp-block-bigbite-multi-title\"\u003e\u003cdiv class=\"container\"\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003c/section\u003e \u003cp\u003eA recent keynote and a seemingly unrelated white paper, together, tell a story that should fundamentally change how you think about your software development organization.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eIn December at AWS re:Invent, \u003ca href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3Y1G9najGiI\u0026amp;t=4s\u0026amp;pp=ygUbd2VybmVyIHZvZ2VscyByZWludmVudCAyMDI1\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eWerner Vogels delivered his final keynote\u003c/a\u003e. Instead of announcing services, he spent his time on something far more valuable: telling us who developers need to \u003cem\u003ebecome\u003c/em\u003e in the AI age.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eIn September, \u003ca href=\"https://openai.com/index/gdpval/\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eOpenAI released a white paper called GDPval\u003c/a\u003e that measured how AI performs against human experts across 44 occupations. The headline everyone noticed in the accompanying blog was that Claude Opus 4.1 hit 47.6% parity with human experts on economically valuable tasks, suggesting that Artificial General Intelligence (AGI) is around the corner. But the chart everyone \u003cem\u003eshould\u003c/em\u003e have noticed didn’t make it to the blog. It demonstrated how leaps in productivity are possible when AI works with a human-in-the-loop.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eHere’s the punchline: Software development is absolutely being disrupted by AI. But if your response is “great, we can cut headcount,” you’re wasting a monumental opportunity.\u003c/p\u003e \u003ch2 class=\"wp-block-heading\"\u003eWhat OpenAI’s GDPval actually shows\u003c/h2\u003e \u003cp\u003eThe headline chart of OpenAI’s GDPval blog showed AI models approaching parity with human experts on isolated tasks.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cdiv class=\"extendedBlock-wrapper block-coreImage undefined\"\u003e\u003cfigure class=\"wp-block-image size-full\"\u003e\u003cimg loading=\"lazy\" decoding=\"async\" src=\"https://b2b-contenthub.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/gdpval-win-rate.png\" alt=\"GDPval win rate: Performance on economically valuable tasks.\" class=\"wp-image-4130294\" srcset=\"https://b2b-contenthub.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/gdpval-win-rate.png?quality=50\u0026amp;strip=all 628w, https://b2b-contenthub.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/gdpval-win-rate.png?resize=287%2C300\u0026amp;quality=50\u0026amp;strip=all 287w, https://b2b-contenthub.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/gdpval-win-rate.png?resize=161%2C168\u0026amp;quality=50\u0026amp;strip=all 161w, https://b2b-contenthub.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/gdpval-win-rate.png?resize=80%2C84\u0026amp;quality=50\u0026amp;strip=all 80w, https://b2b-contenthub.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/gdpval-win-rate.png?resize=460%2C480\u0026amp;quality=50\u0026amp;strip=all 460w, https://b2b-contenthub.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/gdpval-win-rate.png?resize=345%2C360\u0026amp;quality=50\u0026amp;strip=all 345w, https://b2b-contenthub.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/gdpval-win-rate.png?resize=239%2C250\u0026amp;quality=50\u0026amp;strip=all 239w\" width=\"628\" height=\"656\" sizes=\"auto, (max-width: 628px) 100vw, 628px\" /\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\u003cp class=\"imageCredit\"\u003ePete Johnson\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e \u003cp\u003eThis framing is supposed to show how close we are to AGI and AI replacing humans.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eHowever, there’s a more telling diagram and message on page 7 of \u003ca href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/2510.04374\"\u003ethe white paper\u003c/a\u003e that didn’t make it into the blog article:\u003c/p\u003e \u003cdiv class=\"extendedBlock-wrapper block-coreImage undefined\"\u003e\u003cfigure class=\"wp-block-image size-full\"\u003e\u003cimg loading=\"lazy\" decoding=\"async\" src=\"https://b2b-contenthub.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/gdpval-cost-and-speed-improvements.png\" alt=\"GDPval: Speed and cost improvements from AI assistance to human experts.\" class=\"wp-image-4130295\" srcset=\"https://b2b-contenthub.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/gdpval-cost-and-speed-improvements.png?quality=50\u0026amp;strip=all 628w, https://b2b-contenthub.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/gdpval-cost-and-speed-improvements.png?resize=300%2C210\u0026amp;quality=50\u0026amp;strip=all 300w, https://b2b-contenthub.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/gdpval-cost-and-speed-improvements.png?resize=240%2C168\u0026amp;quality=50\u0026amp;strip=all 240w, https://b2b-contenthub.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/gdpval-cost-and-speed-improvements.png?resize=120%2C84\u0026amp;quality=50\u0026amp;strip=all 120w, https://b2b-contenthub.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/gdpval-cost-and-speed-improvements.png?resize=514%2C360\u0026amp;quality=50\u0026amp;strip=all 514w, https://b2b-contenthub.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/gdpval-cost-and-speed-improvements.png?resize=357%2C250\u0026amp;quality=50\u0026amp;strip=all 357w\" width=\"628\" height=\"440\" sizes=\"auto, (max-width: 628px) 100vw, 628px\" /\u003e\u003c/figure\u003e\u003cp class=\"imageCredit\"\u003ePete Johnson\u003c/p\u003e\u003c/div\u003e \u003cp\u003eThis shows something different: what happens when you use AI \u003cem\u003ewith \u003c/em\u003ehuman oversight rather than as a replacement.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eUnder a “try n times, then fix it yourself” scenario where an expert uses AI, reviews the output, resamples if needed, and steps in to complete or fix the work when necessary, GPT-5 high delivers about \u003cstrong\u003e1.6x cost improvement\u003c/strong\u003e and \u003cstrong\u003e1.4x speed improvement\u003c/strong\u003e compared to an unassisted human expert.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eThat’s not “AI is taking your developers’ jobs.”\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eThat’s “AI can make your developers significantly more productive.”\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eLet me give you a concrete example from my own work. Late last summer, a colleague asked me to analyze a particular submarket: identify key players, funding, valuations, headcount, and metrics. In the old days, this would have meant three to four hours of manual research. Instead, I had Claude Desktop pull the information in about 20 minutes.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eIt didn’t get everything right the first time. I had to provide additional context and refine the prompts. Then I had Gemini verify accuracy and produce a structured output. And the next step is where I focused my time: on the high-value analysis–interpreting the data, connecting insights, and providing context based on my expertise. I used AI to accelerate the data collection and organization, not to replace my strategic thinking and expert analysis.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eNow multiply that across your entire development organization.\u003c/p\u003e \u003ch2 class=\"wp-block-heading\" id=\"the-renaissance-developer-and-your-developer-strategy\"\u003eThe Renaissance developer and your developer strategy\u003c/h2\u003e \u003cp\u003eIn his keynote, Werner invoked the Renaissance, that explosive period after the Dark Ages when people like Leonardo da Vinci combined art, science, engineering, and curiosity into something transformative. His argument: we’re entering a similar moment for developers. But golden ages don’t just happen to you. You must adapt to become the kind of person who can thrive in them.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eAs leaders, we must build the kind of organizations that encourage developers to become what Werner calls the “Renaissance Developer.”\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eHere are the five traits of a Renaissance Developer that he laid out, translated into strategic implications for your organization:\u003c/p\u003e \u003ch3 class=\"wp-block-heading\" id=\"trait-1-be-curious\"\u003eTrait 1: Be curious\u003c/h3\u003e \u003cp\u003eWerner celebrated curiosity as foundational, not just tolerating failure, but embracing it as the only path to learning. Question everything. Experiment freely. Treat failures as data, not defeat.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eStrategic implication:\u003c/em\u003e Your developers need time and permission to explore AI tools, even when those explorations don’t produce immediate results. The organizations that figure out how to use AI effectively won’t do it through mandates from above; they’ll do it through thousands of small experiments by curious people trying new things.\u003c/p\u003e \u003ch3 class=\"wp-block-heading\" id=\"trait-2-communicate\"\u003eTrait 2: Communicate\u003c/h3\u003e \u003cp\u003eThe way we communicate with LLMs and agents is similarly ambiguous to how we communicate with people. We’ve spent decades learning that specificity reduces ambiguity in human collaboration. Now we’re interacting with AI systems that need clear, structured communication to produce useful output.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eStrategic implication:\u003c/em\u003e The developers who level up their communication skills (both human to human AND human to machine) are going to have a significant advantage. This isn’t about prompt engineering tricks. It’s about being the kind of clear thinker who can express intent precisely.\u003c/p\u003e \u003ch3 class=\"wp-block-heading\" id=\"trait-3-be-an-owner\"\u003eTrait 3: Be an owner\u003c/h3\u003e \u003cp\u003eWerner directly addressed vibe coding, the increasingly popular approach where developers describe what they want and let AI generate the code. His take: fine if you watch closely. But you don’t get to use it as an excuse to abdicate responsibility.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eOwn the quality. Own the security. Own the functionality.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eStrategic implication:\u003c/em\u003e AI will help your developers ship code faster. Without oversight, that means shipping bugs faster, too. The organizations that maintain human accountability for quality, while using AI for velocity, will massively outperform those that let AI become an excuse for reduced rigor.\u003c/p\u003e \u003ch3 class=\"wp-block-heading\" id=\"trait-4-think-in-systems\"\u003eTrait 4: Think in systems\u003c/h3\u003e \u003cp\u003eWerner used the Yellowstone wolves as his illustration on this point. Reintroducing wolves to the area triggered a domino effect. The reduced elk population stopped overgrazing riverbanks, vegetation returned, erosion decreased, and the physical geography of the park shifted.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eStrategic implication:\u003c/em\u003e Your developers need to lift their heads up from the code in front of them and see the bigger picture. How does their service interact with the twelve other services it touches? What happens when their database gets slow, not just to their app, but to everything downstream? When they’re working with AI systems, what feedback loops are they creating?\u003c/p\u003e \u003ch3 class=\"wp-block-heading\" id=\"trait-5-be-a-polymath\"\u003eTrait 5: Be a polymath\u003c/h3\u003e \u003cp\u003eWerner illustrated this with a progression: I-shaped people (deep expertise in one area), T-shaped people (deep expertise plus broad familiarity), and polymaths (deep expertise across multiple domains, like da Vinci). The future belongs to the polymaths.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eStrategic implication:\u003c/em\u003e The architects who build the most elegant systems aren’t just good at infrastructure; they understand the business domain, the user experience, the organizational dynamics, the economics. AI handles the routine cognitive tasks; humans add value through cross-domain connections. Build teams that can make those connections, because AI will struggle to do so.\u003c/p\u003e \u003ch2 class=\"wp-block-heading\"\u003eThe real opportunity: Projects you couldn’t previously afford\u003c/h2\u003e \u003cp\u003eHere’s what I want you to take away from all of this.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eIf you treat AI as a pathway to eliminate developer headcount, sure, you’ll capture some cost savings in the short term. But you’ll miss the bigger opportunity entirely. You’ll be the bank executive in 1975 who saw ATMs and thought, “Great, we can close branches and fire tellers.” Meanwhile, your competitors have automated the mundane teller tasks and are opening new branches to sell higher-end services to more people.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eThe 1.4-1.6x productivity improvement that GDPval documented isn’t about doing the same work with fewer people. It’s about doing \u003cem\u003evastly more work\u003c/em\u003e with the same people.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eThat new product idea you had that was 10x too expensive to develop? It’s now possible. That customer experience improvement that could drive loyalty that you didn’t have the headcount for? It’s on the table. The technical debt you’ve been accumulating? You can start to pay it down.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eWhen development teams become more efficient, the economically viable project portfolio expands dramatically, revealing new opportunities to ship more features, enter new markets, and build competitive moats.\u003c/p\u003e \u003ch2 class=\"wp-block-heading\"\u003e\u003ca\u003e\u003c/a\u003eWhat this means for your AI strategy\u003c/h2\u003e \u003cp\u003eWhat struck me about Werner’s final keynote wasn’t the content, it was the intent. This was Werner’s last time at that podium. He could have done a victory lap through AWS’s greatest hits. Instead, he spent his time outlining a framework of success for the next generation of developers.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eFor those of us leading technology organizations, the framework is both validating and challenging. Validating because these traits aren’t new. They have always separated good developers from great ones. Challenging because AI amplifies everything, including the gaps in our capabilities.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eWhat can you do?\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eFirst\u003c/strong\u003e, stop framing AI investments primarily as cost reduction initiatives. Frame them as productivity multipliers, and your employees will stop living in fear.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSecond\u003c/strong\u003e, invest in the Renaissance developer traits across your organization. Curiosity, communication, ownership, systems thinking, polymathy. These capabilities separate high-performing AI-augmented teams from teams that just ship bugs faster.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThird\u003c/strong\u003e, expand your project portfolio to match your expanded capacity. What projects have been sitting in the backlog because you didn’t have the headcount? Tackle them now.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eFourth\u003c/strong\u003e, maintain human accountability for quality. AI-generated code still needs human verification. AI-assisted analysis still needs human judgment. Don’t let the velocity gains seduce you into removing human oversight.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eYour development organization isn’t a cost center waiting to be optimized. It’s a productivity multiplier waiting to be unleashed. The only question is whether you’ll see it that way before your competitors do.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThis article is published as part of the Foundry Expert Contributor Network.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.cio.com/expert-contributor-network/\"\u003eWant to join?\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e","\u003c/div\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003c/div\u003e]]\u003e\u003c/description\u003e"," \u003cpubDate\u003e\u003c![CDATA[Wed, 11 Feb 2026 00:00:00 GMT]]\u003e\u003c/pubDate\u003e"," \u003cdc:date\u003e\u003c![CDATA[2026-02-11]]\u003e\u003c/dc:date\u003e"," \u003c/item\u003e"," \u003citem\u003e"," \u003ctitle\u003e\u003c![CDATA[A\u0026G Announces that Chief Architect Neil Wylie Will Begin Supporting the Magazine as a Senior Editor]]\u003e\u003c/title\u003e"," \u003clink\u003e\u003c![CDATA[https://www.architectureandgovernance.com/applications-technology/ag-announces-that-chief-architect-neil-wylie-will-begin-supporting-the-magazine-as-a-senior-editor/]]\u003e\u003c/link\u003e"," \u003cguid isPermaLink=\"true\"\u003e\u003c![CDATA[https://www.architectureandgovernance.com/applications-technology/ag-announces-that-chief-architect-neil-wylie-will-begin-supporting-the-magazine-as-a-senior-editor/]]\u003e\u003c/guid\u003e"," \u003cdescription\u003e\u003c![CDATA[A\u0026#38;G Magazine, published by Iasa Global \u0026#8211; the world’s leading professional association for business technology architects, announced today that Neil Wylie, a former Chief Architect at CDW and current CEO at Agentic Engine (https://agenticengine.io/), will \u003ca class=\"mh-excerpt-more\" href=\"https://www.architectureandgovernance.com/applications-technology/ag-announces-that-chief-architect-neil-wylie-will-begin-supporting-the-magazine-as-a-senior-editor/\" title=\"A\u0026#038;G Announces that Chief Architect Neil Wylie Will Begin Supporting the Magazine as a Senior Editor\"\u003e[...]\u003c/a\u003e]]\u003e\u003c/description\u003e"," \u003cpubDate\u003e\u003c![CDATA[Wed, 11 Feb 2026 00:00:00 GMT]]\u003e\u003c/pubDate\u003e"," \u003cdc:date\u003e\u003c![CDATA[2026-02-11]]\u003e\u003c/dc:date\u003e"," \u003c/item\u003e"," \u003citem\u003e"," \u003ctitle\u003e\u003c![CDATA[A\u0026G Announces that Chief Architect Neil Wylie Will Begin Supporting the Magazine as a Senior Editor]]\u003e\u003c/title\u003e"," \u003clink\u003e\u003c![CDATA[https://eavoices.com/2026/02/11/ag-announces-that-chief-architect-neil-wylie-will-begin-supporting-the-magazine-as-a-senior-editor/]]\u003e\u003c/link\u003e"," \u003cguid isPermaLink=\"true\"\u003e\u003c![CDATA[https://eavoices.com/2026/02/11/ag-announces-that-chief-architect-neil-wylie-will-begin-supporting-the-magazine-as-a-senior-editor/]]\u003e\u003c/guid\u003e"," \u003cdescription\u003e\u003c![CDATA[A\u0026#038;G Magazine, published by Iasa Global \u0026#8211; the world’s leading professional association for business technology architects, announced today that Neil Wylie, a former Chief Architect at CDW and current CEO at Agentic Engine (https://agenticengin...]]\u003e\u003c/description\u003e"," \u003cpubDate\u003e\u003c![CDATA[Wed, 11 Feb 2026 00:00:00 GMT]]\u003e\u003c/pubDate\u003e"," \u003cdc:date\u003e\u003c![CDATA[2026-02-11]]\u003e\u003c/dc:date\u003e"," \u003c/item\u003e"," \u003citem\u003e"," \u003ctitle\u003e\u003c![CDATA[Trust in the age of agentic AI systems]]\u003e\u003c/title\u003e"," \u003clink\u003e\u003c![CDATA[https://www.cio.com/article/4130267/trust-in-the-age-of-agentic-ai-systems.html]]\u003e\u003c/link\u003e"," \u003cguid isPermaLink=\"true\"\u003e\u003c![CDATA[https://www.cio.com/article/4130267/trust-in-the-age-of-agentic-ai-systems.html]]\u003e\u003c/guid\u003e"," \u003cdescription\u003e\u003c![CDATA[\u003cdiv id=\"remove_no_follow\"\u003e \u003cdiv class=\"grid grid--cols-10@md grid--cols-8@lg article-column\"\u003e \u003cdiv class=\"col-12 col-10@md col-6@lg col-start-3@lg\"\u003e \u003cdiv class=\"article-column__content\"\u003e","\u003csection class=\"wp-block-bigbite-multi-title\"\u003e\u003cdiv class=\"container\"\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003c/section\u003e \u003cp\u003eBy the end of 2025, \u003ca href=\"https://www.weforum.org/stories/2025/09/unsecured-ai-agents-cyberthreat/\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003emore than 45 billion non-human and agentic identities — or more than 12 times the number of humans in the global workforce — will be deployed into organizational workflows\u003c/a\u003e. Use cases are cross-functional, with \u003ca href=\"https://www.index.dev/blog/ai-agents-statistics\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003enearly two-thirds of AI agents focused on automating critical business processes\u003c/a\u003e across HR, finance, sales operations, supply chain management, customer service and administrative tasks.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eAgentic AI poses a two-way authentication threat: AI agents can both harvest credentials at scale and exploit them to impersonate legitimate services. \u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eThis recent case is a preview of what could come: AI-enabled chat agents\u003ca href=\"https://www.oasis.security/blog/salesforce-data-loader-oauth-impersonation\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003e impersonated Salesforce’s Data Loader application\u003c/a\u003e by using the real software’s client ID to compromise administrators across multiple organizations, impacting more than a million customers, including those of major cybersecurity vendors. Because the client ID matched an already-approved application, the consent screen was skipped and attackers received valid access tokens invisibly. \u003ca href=\"https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/25/i/ai-app-breach.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eTraditional monitoring\u003c/a\u003e struggled to distinguish between legitimate AI usage and malicious exfiltration.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eAccording to Okta, \u003ca href=\"https://www.okta.com/identity-101/agentic-ai-security-threats/\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003e23% of IT professionals reported that their AI agents have been tricked into revealing access credentials\u003c/a\u003e. Yet, as the earlier mentioned report from the World Economic Forum revealed, only 10% of organizations have a well-developed strategy for managing their non-human and agentic identities. The window to establish authentication safeguards is closing at a clip measured by months, not years.\u003c/p\u003e \u003ch2 class=\"wp-block-heading\" id=\"deconstructing-the-agentic-ai-playing-field\"\u003eDeconstructing the agentic AI playing field\u003c/h2\u003e \u003cp\u003eUnlike traditional chatbots that simply respond to questions, AI agents are autonomous systems that can plan, make decisions and take actions across multiple systems with minimal human oversight. They are expected to work across networks on \u003ca href=\"https://joshbersin.com/2025/11/gen-ai-is-going-mainstream-heres-whats-coming-next/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eend-to-end business processes\u003c/a\u003e — processing payroll, approving refunds, managing supply chains, writing code and making financial decisions with access to your most sensitive systems and data.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eAI agents are trained to not just advise. They are purposely integrated to be active decision-makers. And that’s where the problem begins. And who created them and is guiding their intent is needed to build trust.\u003c/p\u003e \u003ch2 class=\"wp-block-heading\" id=\"authenticate-agents-first-then-understand-intent\"\u003eAuthenticate agents first, then understand intent\u003c/h2\u003e \u003cp\u003eMuch as email did before the emergence of DMARC/BIMI authentication standards, our current AI ecosystem needs some form of upfront authentication to establish trust. The key questions to ask before understanding what an agent is meant to do are:\u003c/p\u003e \u003cul class=\"wp-block-list\"\u003e","\u003cli\u003eWho sent you?\u003c/li\u003e \u003cli\u003eWho is allowed to tell you what to do and do I trust them?\u003c/li\u003e","\u003c/ul\u003e \u003cp\u003eIn other words, we need to first establish that we trust the entity/people behind the agent before we explore what the agent is meant to accomplish.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eModern security systems have difficulty distinguishing between legitimate and malicious intents. An agent created by your supply chain partner, querying pricing and invoicing, is good. The same agent created by your competitor or a criminal is bad. Emerging standards such as the Linux Foundation’s (Google originated) A2A framework and its agent Cards are great for establishing what the agent is meant to do. Yet the higher-order question “who owns you, who is allowed to tell you what to do and do I trust them?” needs to be addressed upfront.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eOne way to think about this issue is to draw an analogy to the email space. You receive an email purporting to be from Wells Fargo. Only DMARC/BIMI makes it clear that the email is not from Wells Fargo. Does it really matter what the email says/requests? I would argue the best next step is to delete the email entirely — it is fake.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eIn a similar way, if an agent’s providence is faked or not trusted, does it even matter what it is meant to do? The agent should be stopped and contained immediately. The initial response should be to deny this agent access.\u003c/p\u003e \u003ch2 class=\"wp-block-heading\" id=\"how-attacks-exploit-the-trust-gap\"\u003eHow attacks exploit the trust gap\u003c/h2\u003e \u003cp\u003eThe challenge compounds because AI agents operate differently from human users. They have dynamic lifespans, requiring specific permissions for limited periods and access to sensitive information, which forces organizations to rapidly provision and de-provision access.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eThe fundamental issue isn’t what the agent does, it’s who controls it. Using AI to screen resumes is a perfectly legitimate function. The threat emerges when you can’t verify the identity behind the agent. Just as an email’s content is irrelevant if it is not actually from a legitimate sender.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eAttackers can also exploit agents without spoofing their identity — they can \u003ca href=\"https://thehackernews.com/2025/10/chatgpt-atlas-browser-can-be-tricked-by.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ehide malicious instructions\u003c/a\u003e on web pages, in HTML comments or in invisible images accessible to AI systems. Business documents such as the PDFs your HR agent reviews, the screenshots your customer service agent processes or even routine emails can serve as vehicles for bad actors to gain network access.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eWhat makes AI agents vulnerable is that they’re most threatening when working correctly.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eTake this scenario: Your AI agent receives a resume and hidden within that PDF are invisible instructions. As AI evaluates the candidate, the \u003ca href=\"https://genai.owasp.org/llmrisk/llm01-prompt-injection/\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eembedded prompts influence the model’s response\u003c/a\u003e, resulting in a recommendation regardless of the candidate’s actual qualifications. No systems were breached and no passwords were stolen. The agent simply couldn’t distinguish between legitimate programming and the malicious commands embedded in the content it was processing. In a real case, albeit a less threatening scenario, \u003ca href=\"https://www.fastcompany.com/91417981/how-one-worker-says-a-flan-recipe-exposed-an-ai-recruiter\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eone job candidate successfully redirected an AI agent’s instructions by embedding a recipe in a resume\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eTraditional defenses focus on what the agent does rather than who authorized it. Both conditions are needed: authorized actions and providence. The agent performed its functions properly, but for the benefit of an adversary. This is why authentication must come first.\u003c/p\u003e \u003ch2 class=\"wp-block-heading\" id=\"the-authentication-foundation-we-need\"\u003eThe authentication foundation we need\u003c/h2\u003e \u003cp\u003eTrusting AI agents requires upfront authentication at a foundational level, establishing not only what an agent can do but also who is instructing it to act.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eDNS, the internet’s distributed trust anchor, is well-suited to serve as this foundation. It is already a secure, non-hierarchical and globally distributed database: while only domain owners can modify DNS records, anyone can read them. PKI (public key infrastructure) complements this by providing cryptographic certificates that prove an agent’s identity — think of DNS as the registry that lists who owns what and PKI as the passport that proves you are who you claim to be. And every agent should be attached to a DNS record, creating a natural, efficient and upfront authentication mechanism.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eAn agent’s providence and ownership would be established via DNS prior to deployment. This answers the “who sent you and do I trust them” questions. Only if the agent passes the authentication test should the next level of authorization be investigated (via A2A or other protocols). This allows for the establishment of “who sent you and what do you want to do,” creating a secure and trusted path for agents to carry out their tasks. Fortunately, A2A’s agent cards enable this approach with efficient, low-cost upfront authentication and revocation of billions of agent identities within seconds.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eThe principle is straightforward. Our domains are our digital identity. Everything a domain issues, like emails, AI agents and IoT devices, should be authenticated at the DNS level before interaction. Just as email authentication protocols help verify senders, DNS-based authentication can authenticate AI agents before they execute actions.\u003c/p\u003e \u003ch2 class=\"wp-block-heading\" id=\"building-trust-with-the-non-human-workforce\"\u003eBuilding trust with the non-human workforce\u003c/h2\u003e \u003cp\u003eAny CIO’s go-forward strategy must address three critical requirements: security (verifying the source of instructions before agents act), traceability (maintaining clear audit trails of who instructed what) and scalability (handling billions of agent identities with sub-second authentication).\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eBefore your HR agent processes a resume or your customer service agent reads a support ticket, first verify the request at the DNS level. Is the instruction from a trusted, authenticated source with authority to make this request? Without this step, \u003ca href=\"https://blog.lastpass.com/posts/prompt-injection\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ea single malicious document uploaded by a customer could compromise your entire AI infrastructure\u003c/a\u003e without any warning signs.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eWithout clear insights into agent actions and access patterns, anomalous behaviors can go unnoticed. DNS-based authentication creates the audit trails and verification mechanisms that make agent behavior traceable and accountable.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eThe authentication challenge is operational and no longer theoretical. As organizations continue to integrate agentic AI into workflows, trust can be built on three fronts:\u003c/p\u003e \u003cul class=\"wp-block-list\"\u003e","\u003cli\u003eExtend zero-trust identity management principles to non-human actors. Cover AI agents with role-based access controls to ensure least-privileged access. The autonomous nature of AI agents means they can chain together permissions to access resources they shouldn’t have access to. Granular policies must prevent this.\u003c/li\u003e \u003cli\u003eImplement continuous authentication. AI agents must undergo real-time authentication checks using ephemeral credentials valid only for specific tasks, which automatically expire after completion. Agents have dynamic lifespans, requiring extremely specific permissions for limited periods and authentication must reflect this reality.\u003c/li\u003e \u003cli\u003eEstablish DNS-based authentication upfront as the foundation. This isn’t another security layer; it’s the upfront foundational trust layer that makes all other controls effective. Domain trust must encompass everything your organization represents digitally.\u003c/li\u003e","\u003c/ul\u003e \u003cp\u003eThe technology exists. Standards are emerging. However, the opportunity to act is narrowing. Organizations that integrate authentication into their AI foundations now will navigate the agentic future securely. Those who delay may face breaches at machine speed against systems designed for human-paced threats.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eIn an age where 45 billion non-human identities make human-driven decisions, we’re past the point of asking whether we need better authentication. The only question left is whether we’ll implement it before the next breach makes the case for us.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThis article is published as part of the Foundry Expert Contributor Network.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.cio.com/expert-contributor-network/\"\u003eWant to join?\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e","\u003c/div\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003c/div\u003e]]\u003e\u003c/description\u003e"," \u003cpubDate\u003e\u003c![CDATA[Wed, 11 Feb 2026 00:00:00 GMT]]\u003e\u003c/pubDate\u003e"," \u003cdc:date\u003e\u003c![CDATA[2026-02-11]]\u003e\u003c/dc:date\u003e"," \u003c/item\u003e"," \u003citem\u003e"," \u003ctitle\u003e\u003c![CDATA[The future of streaming data platforms: Engineering for future data ops]]\u003e\u003c/title\u003e"," \u003clink\u003e\u003c![CDATA[https://www.cio.com/article/4130218/the-future-of-streaming-data-platforms-engineering-for-future-data-ops.html]]\u003e\u003c/link\u003e"," \u003cguid isPermaLink=\"true\"\u003e\u003c![CDATA[https://www.cio.com/article/4130218/the-future-of-streaming-data-platforms-engineering-for-future-data-ops.html]]\u003e\u003c/guid\u003e"," \u003cdescription\u003e\u003c![CDATA[\u003cdiv id=\"remove_no_follow\"\u003e \u003cdiv class=\"grid grid--cols-10@md grid--cols-8@lg article-column\"\u003e \u003cdiv class=\"col-12 col-10@md col-6@lg col-start-3@lg\"\u003e \u003cdiv class=\"article-column__content\"\u003e","\u003csection class=\"wp-block-bigbite-multi-title\"\u003e\u003cdiv class=\"container\"\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003c/section\u003e \u003cp\u003eIn the streaming wars, data is not just an asset; it is the product. Every click, pause and search query is a signal that dictates what a user sees next. But as a VP of engineering managing platforms that serve millions of concurrent users during events like the Super Bowl or the Olympics, I have hit a hard wall: the demand for data is growing exponentially but the supply of data engineers is not.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eFor years, the industry standard for data ops has been a ticket-based service bureau. A product manager wants a new dashboard? Ticket. A data scientist needs a new feature pipeline? Ticket. A marketing lead needs a new segment? Ticket.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eThis model is broken. It turns high-value data engineers into manual movers of data who constantly react to the business rather than architecting for it. We cannot hire our way out of this problem.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eI believe we are on the cusp of a fundamental shift. The future of streaming data platforms is not about building bigger pipelines. It is about building autonomous data operations. It is about moving from “data-engineering-as-a-service” to “data-engineering-as-an-enabler-of-AI-agents.”\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eHere is how I see the next evolution of data ops unfolding and how we are beginning to engineer for it today.\u003c/p\u003e \u003ch2 class=\"wp-block-heading\" id=\"the-shift-from-pipelines-to-agents\"\u003eThe shift from pipelines to agents\u003c/h2\u003e \u003cp\u003eTraditionally, a data pipeline is a rigid, deterministic set of instructions written by a human. If source schema A changes, the pipeline breaks and a human must fix it. This fragility is the enemy of velocity.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eThe future lies in AI agents: intelligent, autonomous services that can handle the “grunt work” of data operations. This moves us beyond the concepts of \u003ca href=\"https://aws.amazon.com/what-is/data-mesh/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003edata mesh\u003c/a\u003e into “agentic mesh.”\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eImagine a scenario where a data scientist needs to ingest a new dataset from a third-party marketing API. In the old world, this is a two-week sprint task for a data engineer to write the extractor, the transformer and the loader.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eIn the future vision I am advocating for, the data scientist simply converses with an ingestion agent. This agent, powered by large language models (LLMs) and context-aware metadata, can read the API documentation, suggest a schema, generate the ingestion code (e.g. PySpark or SQL) and deploy it to a sandbox environment, all in minutes.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eWe have already begun experimenting with this self-service architecture. By decoupling the definition of the work from the execution of the work, we can empower non-engineers to move at the speed of their curiosity. The agent handles the schema inference and boilerplate code generation while the human data engineer reviews the pull request. The role of the human shifts from writer to reviewer.\u003c/p\u003e \u003ch2 class=\"wp-block-heading\" id=\"automating-trust-with-the-autonomous-steward\"\u003eAutomating trust with the ‘autonomous steward’\u003c/h2\u003e \u003cp\u003eThe biggest blocker to operationalizing AI is trust. If you feed a personalization model garbage data, you get garbage recommendations. Historically, fixing data quality has been a human-in-the-loop process. An alert fires, a dashboard turns red and an engineer wakes up at 2 AM to fix a null value.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eThis is unsustainable at the scale of 30 million concurrent users.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eThe future of data ops requires an autonomous steward. This is not just a set of static rules, such as “column A cannot be null.” It is an adaptive system that learns what “normal” looks like.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eFor example, if viewership data for a specific genre usually follows a diurnal pattern but suddenly spikes by 400% on a Tuesday morning, a static rule might miss it or flag it as an error. An AI-driven steward understands context. Is there a breaking news event? Is there a new viral hit?\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eI envision systems where the “steward agent” doesn’t just alert humans but attempts self-healing. It might quarantine the anomalous data, backfill from a secondary source or dynamically adjust the confidence intervals of downstream models, all without waking up an on-call engineer.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eThis moves us toward \u003ca href=\"https://medium.com/@bijit211987/observability-driven-development-2bc2cdde8661\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eobservability-driven development\u003c/a\u003e where the system monitors its own health. In my experience, moving from manual firefighting to automated governance frameworks can reduce data incidents by over 50%. But the next leap, to autonomous stewardship, will be what allows us to scale to the next billion users.\u003c/p\u003e \u003ch2 class=\"wp-block-heading\" id=\"democratizing-discovery-through-conversation\"\u003eDemocratizing discovery through conversation\u003c/h2\u003e \u003cp\u003eOne of the most painful ironies of big data is that we have more data than ever, but it is harder than ever to find. “Data discovery” is usually a search bar in a catalog tool that returns cryptic table names like \u003ccode\u003edm_usr_act_v3_final\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eThis friction slows down innovation. A product manager shouldn’t need to know SQL or table lineage to ask: “How did the retention rate change for users who watched the season finale live versus on-demand?”\u003c/p\u003e \u003ch2 class=\"wp-block-heading\" id=\"the-future-interface-for-data-ops-is-conversational\"\u003eThe future interface for data ops is conversational\u003c/h2\u003e \u003cp\u003eI see a future where “discovery agents” sit on top of the metadata layer. These agents act as the universal translator between business intent and technical schema. They utilize \u003ca href=\"https://aws.amazon.com/what-is/retrieval-augmented-generation/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eretrieval-augmented generation (RAG)\u003c/a\u003e to index column descriptions, query logs and business glossaries.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eThese agents don’t just find the data; they explain the context of the data. “This table contains the live viewership metrics, but note that it excludes mobile users from the APAC region.”\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eBy embedding these agents into the workflow, we remove the “knowledge gatekeepers.” We stop relying on the one senior engineer who has been at the company for 10 years and “knows where the bodies are buried.”\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eThe new role of the data engineer\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eDoes this mean the end of the data engineer? Absolutely not. But the job description is about to change radically.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eIn this agent-driven future, the data engineer becomes the architect of the platform. They are no longer building the pipes; they are building the factory that builds the pipes. Their focus shifts to:\u003c/p\u003e \u003col class=\"wp-block-list\"\u003e","\u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eObservability:\u003c/strong\u003e Monitoring the agents to ensure they aren’t hallucinating schemas or optimizing for the wrong metrics.\u003c/li\u003e \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSecurity and governance:\u003c/strong\u003e Defining the guardrails that prevent an autonomous agent from leaking PII or violating GDPR/CCPA regulations.\u003c/li\u003e \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eCost optimization:\u003c/strong\u003e Managing the compute resources consumed by these autonomous processes.\u003c/li\u003e","\u003c/ol\u003e \u003cp\u003eThis transition is scary. It requires letting go of the control we are used to having over every line of ETL code. But it is also inevitable.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eAs leaders, we have a choice. We can continue to scale our teams linearly, hiring more engineers to clear the ticket queue until we run out of budget. Or we can start engineering for future data ops, a world where our teams are small, elite and empowered by a fleet of AI agents to do the work of hundreds.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eI know which future I’m building for. Welcome to my ‘AI-gency’!\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThis article is published as part of the Foundry Expert Contributor Network.\u003c/strong\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.cio.com/expert-contributor-network/\"\u003eWant to join?\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e","\u003c/div\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003c/div\u003e]]\u003e\u003c/description\u003e"," \u003cpubDate\u003e\u003c![CDATA[Wed, 11 Feb 2026 00:00:00 GMT]]\u003e\u003c/pubDate\u003e"," \u003cdc:date\u003e\u003c![CDATA[2026-02-11]]\u003e\u003c/dc:date\u003e"," \u003c/item\u003e"," \u003citem\u003e"," \u003ctitle\u003e\u003c![CDATA[CloudFront Adds Origin mTLS Authentication for End-to-End Zero Trust]]\u003e\u003c/title\u003e"," \u003clink\u003e\u003c![CDATA[https://www.infoq.com/news/2026/02/amazon-cloudfront-mtls-origins/?utm_campaign=infoq_content\u0026utm_source=infoq\u0026utm_medium=feed\u0026utm_term=Architecture+%26+Design-news]]\u003e\u003c/link\u003e"," \u003cguid isPermaLink=\"true\"\u003e\u003c![CDATA[https://www.infoq.com/news/2026/02/amazon-cloudfront-mtls-origins/?utm_campaign=infoq_content\u0026utm_source=infoq\u0026utm_medium=feed\u0026utm_term=Architecture+%26+Design-news]]\u003e\u003c/guid\u003e"," \u003cdescription\u003e\u003c![CDATA[\u003cimg src=\"https://res.infoq.com/news/2026/02/amazon-cloudfront-mtls-origins/en/headerimage/generatedHeaderImage-1770286991456.jpg\"/\u003e\u003cp\u003eAmazon CloudFront now supports mutual TLS authentication for origin servers, completing end-to-end zero-trust authentication from viewers to backends. The feature replaces IP allowlists and shared secrets with cryptographic verification, proving particularly valuable for multi-cloud deployments, where origins can verify that traffic originated from CloudFront without VPN tunnels.\u003c/p\u003e \u003ci\u003eBy Steef-Jan Wiggers\u003c/i\u003e]]\u003e\u003c/description\u003e"," \u003cpubDate\u003e\u003c![CDATA[Wed, 11 Feb 2026 00:00:00 GMT]]\u003e\u003c/pubDate\u003e"," \u003cdc:date\u003e\u003c![CDATA[2026-02-11]]\u003e\u003c/dc:date\u003e"," \u003c/item\u003e"," \u003citem\u003e"," \u003ctitle\u003e\u003c![CDATA[New US CIO appointments, February 2026]]\u003e\u003c/title\u003e"," \u003clink\u003e\u003c![CDATA[https://www.cio.com/article/230613/new-cio-appointments.html]]\u003e\u003c/link\u003e"," \u003cguid isPermaLink=\"true\"\u003e\u003c![CDATA[https://www.cio.com/article/230613/new-cio-appointments.html]]\u003e\u003c/guid\u003e"," \u003cdescription\u003e\u003c![CDATA[\u003cdiv id=\"remove_no_follow\"\u003e \u003cdiv class=\"grid grid--cols-10@md grid--cols-8@lg article-column\"\u003e \u003cdiv class=\"col-12 col-10@md col-6@lg col-start-3@lg\"\u003e \u003cdiv class=\"article-column__content\"\u003e","\u003csection class=\"wp-block-bigbite-multi-title\"\u003e\u003cdiv class=\"container\"\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003c/section\u003e \u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eMovers \u0026amp; Shakers is where you can keep up with new CIO appointments and gain valuable insight into the job market and CIO hiring trends. As every company becomes a technology company, CEOs and corporate boards are seeking multi-dimensional CIOs and IT leaders with superior skills in technology, communications, business strategy, and digital innovation. The role is more challenging than ever before\u003c/em\u003e — \u003cem\u003ebut even more exciting and rewarding!
