class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e]]\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u0026lt;/\u003cspan class=\"pl-ent\"\u003eguid\u003c/span\u003e\u0026gt;"," \u0026lt;\u003cspan class=\"pl-ent\"\u003edescription\u003c/span\u003e\u0026gt;\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e\u0026lt;![CDATA[\u003c/span\u003e\u0026lt;div id=\u0026quot;remove_no_follow\u0026quot;\u0026gt; \u0026lt;div class=\u0026quot;grid grid--cols-10@md grid--cols-8@lg article-column\u0026quot;\u0026gt; \u0026lt;div class=\u0026quot;col-12 col-10@md col-6@lg col-start-3@lg\u0026quot;\u0026gt; \u0026lt;div class=\u0026quot;article-column__content\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;section class=\u0026quot;wp-block-bigbite-multi-title\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u0026lt;div class=\u0026quot;container\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/div\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/section\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;By the end of 2025, \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://www.weforum.org/stories/2025/09/unsecured-ai-agents-cyberthreat/\u0026quot; rel=\u0026quot;nofollow\u0026quot;\u0026gt;more than 45 billion non-human and agentic identities — or more than 12 times the number of humans in the global workforce — will be deployed into organizational workflows\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt;. Use cases are cross-functional, with \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://www.index.dev/blog/ai-agents-statistics\u0026quot; rel=\u0026quot;nofollow\u0026quot;\u0026gt;nearly two-thirds of AI agents focused on automating critical business processes\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt; across HR, finance, sales operations, supply chain management, customer service and administrative tasks.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Agentic AI poses a two-way authentication threat: AI agents can both harvest credentials at scale and exploit them to impersonate legitimate services. \u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;This recent case is a preview of what could come: AI-enabled chat agents\u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://www.oasis.security/blog/salesforce-data-loader-oauth-impersonation\u0026quot; target=\u0026quot;_blank\u0026quot; rel=\u0026quot;nofollow\u0026quot;\u0026gt; impersonated Salesforce’s Data Loader application\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt; by using the real software’s client ID to compromise administrators across multiple organizations, impacting more than a million customers, including those of major cybersecurity vendors. Because the client ID matched an already-approved application, the consent screen was skipped and attackers received valid access tokens invisibly. \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/25/i/ai-app-breach.html\u0026quot; target=\u0026quot;_blank\u0026quot; rel=\u0026quot;nofollow\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Traditional monitoring\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt; struggled to distinguish between legitimate AI usage and malicious exfiltration.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;According to Okta, \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://www.okta.com/identity-101/agentic-ai-security-threats/\u0026quot; rel=\u0026quot;nofollow\u0026quot;\u0026gt;23% of IT professionals reported that their AI agents have been tricked into revealing access credentials\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt;. Yet, as the earlier mentioned report from the World Economic Forum revealed, only 10% of organizations have a well-developed strategy for managing their non-human and agentic identities. The window to establish authentication safeguards is closing at a clip measured by months, not years.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h2 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;deconstructing-the-agentic-ai-playing-field\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Deconstructing the agentic AI playing field\u0026lt;/h2\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Unlike traditional chatbots that simply respond to questions, AI agents are autonomous systems that can plan, make decisions and take actions across multiple systems with minimal human oversight. They are expected to work across networks on \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://joshbersin.com/2025/11/gen-ai-is-going-mainstream-heres-whats-coming-next/\u0026quot; target=\u0026quot;_blank\u0026quot; rel=\u0026quot;nofollow\u0026quot;\u0026gt;end-to-end business processes\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt; — processing payroll, approving refunds, managing supply chains, writing code and making financial decisions with access to your most sensitive systems and data.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;AI agents are trained to not just advise. They are purposely integrated to be active decision-makers. And that’s where the problem begins. And who created them and is guiding their intent is needed to build trust.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h2 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;authenticate-agents-first-then-understand-intent\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Authenticate agents first, then understand intent\u0026lt;/h2\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Much as email did before the emergence of DMARC/BIMI authentication standards, our current AI ecosystem needs some form of upfront authentication to establish trust. The key questions to ask before understanding what an agent is meant to do are:\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;ul class=\u0026quot;wp-block-list\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Who sent you?\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Who is allowed to tell you what to do and do I trust them?\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;/ul\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;In other words, we need to first establish that we trust the entity/people behind the agent before we explore what the agent is meant to accomplish.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Modern security systems have difficulty distinguishing between legitimate and malicious intents. An agent created by your supply chain partner, querying pricing and invoicing, is good. The same agent created by your competitor or a criminal is bad. Emerging standards such as the Linux Foundation’s (Google originated) A2A framework and its agent Cards are great for establishing what the agent is meant to do. Yet the higher-order question “who owns you, who is allowed to tell you what to do and do I trust them?” needs to be addressed upfront.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;One way to think about this issue is to draw an analogy to the email space. You receive an email purporting to be from Wells Fargo. Only DMARC/BIMI makes it clear that the email is not from Wells Fargo. Does it really matter what the email says/requests? I would argue the best next step is to delete the email entirely — it is fake.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;In a similar way, if an agent’s providence is faked or not trusted, does it even matter what it is meant to do? The agent should be stopped and contained immediately. The initial response should be to deny this agent access.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h2 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;how-attacks-exploit-the-trust-gap\u0026quot;\u0026gt;How attacks exploit the trust gap\u0026lt;/h2\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;The challenge compounds because AI agents operate differently from human users. They have dynamic lifespans, requiring specific permissions for limited periods and access to sensitive information, which forces organizations to rapidly provision and de-provision access.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;The fundamental issue isn’t what the agent does, it’s who controls it. Using AI to screen resumes is a perfectly legitimate function. The threat emerges when you can’t verify the identity behind the agent. Just as an email’s content is irrelevant if it is not actually from a legitimate sender.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Attackers can also exploit agents without spoofing their identity — they can \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://thehackernews.com/2025/10/chatgpt-atlas-browser-can-be-tricked-by.html\u0026quot; target=\u0026quot;_blank\u0026quot; rel=\u0026quot;nofollow\u0026quot;\u0026gt;hide malicious instructions\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt; on web pages, in HTML comments or in invisible images accessible to AI systems. Business documents such as the PDFs your HR agent reviews, the screenshots your customer service agent processes or even routine emails can serve as vehicles for bad actors to gain network access.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;What makes AI agents vulnerable is that they’re most threatening when working correctly.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Take this scenario: Your AI agent receives a resume and hidden within that PDF are invisible instructions. As AI evaluates the candidate, the \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://genai.owasp.org/llmrisk/llm01-prompt-injection/\u0026quot; rel=\u0026quot;nofollow\u0026quot;\u0026gt;embedded prompts influence the model’s response\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt;, resulting in a recommendation regardless of the candidate’s actual qualifications. No systems were breached and no passwords were stolen. The agent simply couldn’t distinguish between legitimate programming and the malicious commands embedded in the content it was processing. In a real case, albeit a less threatening scenario, \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://www.fastcompany.com/91417981/how-one-worker-says-a-flan-recipe-exposed-an-ai-recruiter\u0026quot; rel=\u0026quot;nofollow\u0026quot;\u0026gt;one job candidate successfully redirected an AI agent’s instructions by embedding a recipe in a resume\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt;.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Traditional defenses focus on what the agent does rather than who authorized it. Both conditions are needed: authorized actions and providence. The agent performed its functions properly, but for the benefit of an adversary. This is why authentication must come first.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h2 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;the-authentication-foundation-we-need\u0026quot;\u0026gt;The authentication foundation we need\u0026lt;/h2\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Trusting AI agents requires upfront authentication at a foundational level, establishing not only what an agent can do but also who is instructing it to act.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;DNS, the internet’s distributed trust anchor, is well-suited to serve as this foundation. It is already a secure, non-hierarchical and globally distributed database: while only domain owners can modify DNS records, anyone can read them. PKI (public key infrastructure) complements this by providing cryptographic certificates that prove an agent’s identity — think of DNS as the registry that lists who owns what and PKI as the passport that proves you are who you claim to be. And every agent should be attached to a DNS record, creating a natural, efficient and upfront authentication mechanism.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;An agent’s providence and ownership would be established via DNS prior to deployment. This answers the “who sent you and do I trust them” questions. Only if the agent passes the authentication test should the next level of authorization be investigated (via A2A or other protocols). This allows for the establishment of “who sent you and what do you want to do,” creating a secure and trusted path for agents to carry out their tasks. Fortunately, A2A’s agent cards enable this approach with efficient, low-cost upfront authentication and revocation of billions of agent identities within seconds.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;The principle is straightforward. Our domains are our digital identity. Everything a domain issues, like emails, AI agents and IoT devices, should be authenticated at the DNS level before interaction. Just as email authentication protocols help verify senders, DNS-based authentication can authenticate AI agents before they execute actions.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h2 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;building-trust-with-the-non-human-workforce\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Building trust with the non-human workforce\u0026lt;/h2\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Any CIO’s go-forward strategy must address three critical requirements: security (verifying the source of instructions before agents act), traceability (maintaining clear audit trails of who instructed what) and scalability (handling billions of agent identities with sub-second authentication).\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Before your HR agent processes a resume or your customer service agent reads a support ticket, first verify the request at the DNS level. Is the instruction from a trusted, authenticated source with authority to make this request? Without this step, \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://blog.lastpass.com/posts/prompt-injection\u0026quot; rel=\u0026quot;nofollow\u0026quot;\u0026gt;a single malicious document uploaded by a customer could compromise your entire AI infrastructure\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt; without any warning signs.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Without clear insights into agent actions and access patterns, anomalous behaviors can go unnoticed. DNS-based authentication creates the audit trails and verification mechanisms that make agent behavior traceable and accountable.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;The authentication challenge is operational and no longer theoretical. As organizations continue to integrate agentic AI into workflows, trust can be built on three fronts:\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;ul class=\u0026quot;wp-block-list\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Extend zero-trust identity management principles to non-human actors. Cover AI agents with role-based access controls to ensure least-privileged access. The autonomous nature of AI agents means they can chain together permissions to access resources they shouldn’t have access to. Granular policies must prevent this.\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Implement continuous authentication. AI agents must undergo real-time authentication checks using ephemeral credentials valid only for specific tasks, which automatically expire after completion. Agents have dynamic lifespans, requiring extremely specific permissions for limited periods and authentication must reflect this reality.\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;Establish DNS-based authentication upfront as the foundation. This isn’t another security layer; it’s the upfront foundational trust layer that makes all other controls effective. Domain trust must encompass everything your organization represents digitally.\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;/ul\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;The technology exists. Standards are emerging. However, the opportunity to act is narrowing. Organizations that integrate authentication into their AI foundations now will navigate the agentic future securely. Those who delay may face breaches at machine speed against systems designed for human-paced threats.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;In an age where 45 billion non-human identities make human-driven decisions, we’re past the point of asking whether we need better authentication. The only question left is whether we’ll implement it before the next breach makes the case for us.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;This article is published as part of the Foundry Expert Contributor Network.\u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt;\u0026lt;br\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;\u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://www.cio.com/expert-contributor-network/\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Want to join?\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;/div\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/div\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/div\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/div\u0026gt;\u003cspan Engineering for future data ops\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e]]\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u0026lt;/\u003cspan class=\"pl-ent\"\u003etitle\u003c/span\u003e\u0026gt;"," class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e]]\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u0026lt;/\u003cspan class=\"pl-ent\"\u003elink\u003c/span\u003e\u0026gt;"," \u0026lt;\u003cspan class=\"pl-ent\"\u003eguid\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-e\"\u003eisPermaLink\u003c/span\u003e=\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e\u0026quot;\u003c/span\u003etrue\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e\u0026quot;\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u0026gt;\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e\u0026lt;![CDATA[\u003c/span\u003ehttps://www.cio.com/article/4130218/the-future-of-streaming-data-platforms-engineering-for-future-data-ops.html\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e]]\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u0026lt;/\u003cspan class=\"pl-ent\"\u003eguid\u003c/span\u003e\u0026gt;"," \u0026lt;\u003cspan class=\"pl-ent\"\u003edescription\u003c/span\u003e\u0026gt;\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e\u0026lt;![CDATA[\u003c/span\u003e\u0026lt;div id=\u0026quot;remove_no_follow\u0026quot;\u0026gt; \u0026lt;div class=\u0026quot;grid grid--cols-10@md grid--cols-8@lg article-column\u0026quot;\u0026gt; \u0026lt;div class=\u0026quot;col-12 col-10@md col-6@lg col-start-3@lg\u0026quot;\u0026gt; \u0026lt;div class=\u0026quot;article-column__content\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;section class=\u0026quot;wp-block-bigbite-multi-title\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u0026lt;div class=\u0026quot;container\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/div\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/section\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;In the streaming wars, data is not just an asset; it is the product. Every click, pause and search query is a signal that dictates what a user sees next. But as a VP of engineering managing platforms that serve millions of concurrent users during events like the Super Bowl or the Olympics, I have hit a hard wall: the demand for data is growing exponentially but the supply of data engineers is not.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;For years, the industry standard for data ops has been a ticket-based service bureau. A product manager wants a new dashboard? Ticket. A data scientist needs a new feature pipeline? Ticket. A marketing lead needs a new segment? Ticket.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;This model is broken. It turns high-value data engineers into manual movers of data who constantly react to the business rather than architecting for it. We cannot hire our way out of this problem.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;I believe we are on the cusp of a fundamental shift. The future of streaming data platforms is not about building bigger pipelines. It is about building autonomous data operations. It is about moving from “data-engineering-as-a-service” to “data-engineering-as-an-enabler-of-AI-agents.”\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Here is how I see the next evolution of data ops unfolding and how we are beginning to engineer for it today.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h2 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;the-shift-from-pipelines-to-agents\u0026quot;\u0026gt;The shift from pipelines to agents\u0026lt;/h2\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Traditionally, a data pipeline is a rigid, deterministic set of instructions written by a human. If source schema A changes, the pipeline breaks and a human must fix it. This fragility is the enemy of velocity.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;The future lies in AI agents: intelligent, autonomous services that can handle the “grunt work” of data operations. This moves us beyond the concepts of \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://aws.amazon.com/what-is/data-mesh/\u0026quot; target=\u0026quot;_blank\u0026quot; rel=\u0026quot;nofollow\u0026quot;\u0026gt;data mesh\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt; into “agentic mesh.”\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Imagine a scenario where a data scientist needs to ingest a new dataset from a third-party marketing API. In the old world, this is a two-week sprint task for a data engineer to write the extractor, the transformer and the loader.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;In the future vision I am advocating for, the data scientist simply converses with an ingestion agent. This agent, powered by large language models (LLMs) and context-aware metadata, can read the API documentation, suggest a schema, generate the ingestion code (e.g. PySpark or SQL) and deploy it to a sandbox environment, all in minutes.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;We have already begun experimenting with this self-service architecture. By decoupling the definition of the work from the execution of the work, we can empower non-engineers to move at the speed of their curiosity. The agent handles the schema inference and boilerplate code generation while the human data engineer reviews the pull request. The role of the human shifts from writer to reviewer.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h2 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;automating-trust-with-the-autonomous-steward\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Automating trust with the ‘autonomous steward’\u0026lt;/h2\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;The biggest blocker to operationalizing AI is trust. If you feed a personalization model garbage data, you get garbage recommendations. Historically, fixing data quality has been a human-in-the-loop process. An alert fires, a dashboard turns red and an engineer wakes up at 2 AM to fix a null value.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;This is unsustainable at the scale of 30 million concurrent users.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;The future of data ops requires an autonomous steward. This is not just a set of static rules, such as “column A cannot be null.” It is an adaptive system that learns what “normal” looks like.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;For example, if viewership data for a specific genre usually follows a diurnal pattern but suddenly spikes by 400% on a Tuesday morning, a static rule might miss it or flag it as an error. An AI-driven steward understands context. Is there a breaking news event? Is there a new viral hit?\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;I envision systems where the “steward agent” doesn’t just alert humans but attempts self-healing. It might quarantine the anomalous data, backfill from a secondary source or dynamically adjust the confidence intervals of downstream models, all without waking up an on-call engineer.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;This moves us toward \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://medium.com/@bijit211987/observability-driven-development-2bc2cdde8661\u0026quot; target=\u0026quot;_blank\u0026quot; rel=\u0026quot;nofollow\u0026quot;\u0026gt;observability-driven development\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt; where the system monitors its own health. In my experience, moving from manual firefighting to automated governance frameworks can reduce data incidents by over 50%. But the next leap, to autonomous stewardship, will be what allows us to scale to the next billion users.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h2 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;democratizing-discovery-through-conversation\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Democratizing discovery through conversation\u0026lt;/h2\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;One of the most painful ironies of big data is that we have more data than ever, but it is harder than ever to find. “Data discovery” is usually a search bar in a catalog tool that returns cryptic table names like \u0026lt;code\u0026gt;dm_usr_act_v3_final\u0026lt;/code\u0026gt;.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;This friction slows down innovation. A product manager shouldn’t need to know SQL or table lineage to ask: “How did the retention rate change for users who watched the season finale live versus on-demand?”\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h2 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;the-future-interface-for-data-ops-is-conversational\u0026quot;\u0026gt;The future interface for data ops is conversational\u0026lt;/h2\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;I see a future where “discovery agents” sit on top of the metadata layer. These agents act as the universal translator between business intent and technical schema. They utilize \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://aws.amazon.com/what-is/retrieval-augmented-generation/\u0026quot; target=\u0026quot;_blank\u0026quot; rel=\u0026quot;nofollow\u0026quot;\u0026gt;retrieval-augmented generation (RAG)\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt; to index column descriptions, query logs and business glossaries.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;These agents don’t just find the data; they explain the context of the data. “This table contains the live viewership metrics, but note that it excludes mobile users from the APAC region.”\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;By embedding these agents into the workflow, we remove the “knowledge gatekeepers.” We stop relying on the one senior engineer who has been at the company for 10 years and “knows where the bodies are buried.”\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;The new role of the data engineer\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Does this mean the end of the data engineer? Absolutely not. But the job description is about to change radically.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;In this agent-driven future, the data engineer becomes the architect of the platform. They are no longer building the pipes; they are building the factory that builds the pipes. Their focus shifts to:\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;ol class=\u0026quot;wp-block-list\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;li\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;Observability:\u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt; Monitoring the agents to ensure they aren’t hallucinating schemas or optimizing for the wrong metrics.\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;Security and governance:\u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt; Defining the guardrails that prevent an autonomous agent from leaking PII or violating GDPR/CCPA regulations.\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;Cost optimization:\u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt; Managing the compute resources consumed by these autonomous processes.\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;/ol\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;This transition is scary. It requires letting go of the control we are used to having over every line of ETL code. But it is also inevitable.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;As leaders, we have a choice. We can continue to scale our teams linearly, hiring more engineers to clear the ticket queue until we run out of budget. Or we can start engineering for future data ops, a world where our teams are small, elite and empowered by a fleet of AI agents to do the work of hundreds.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;I know which future I’m building for. Welcome to my ‘AI-gency’!\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;This article is published as part of the Foundry Expert Contributor Network.\u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt;\u0026lt;br\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;\u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://www.cio.com/expert-contributor-network/\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Want to join?\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan src=\u0026quot;https://res.infoq.com/news/2026/02/amazon-cloudfront-mtls-origins/en/headerimage/generatedHeaderImage-1770286991456.jpg\u0026quot;/\u0026gt;\u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Amazon CloudFront now supports mutual TLS authentication for origin servers, completing end-to-end zero-trust authentication from viewers to backends. The feature replaces IP allowlists and shared secrets with cryptographic verification, proving particularly valuable for multi-cloud deployments, where origins can verify that traffic originated from CloudFront without VPN tunnels.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;i\u0026gt;By Steef-Jan Wiggers\u0026lt;/i\u0026gt;\u003cspan \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;\u0026lt;em\u0026gt;Movers \u0026amp;amp; Shakers is where you can keep up with new CIO appointments and gain valuable insight into the job market and CIO hiring trends. As every company becomes a technology company, CEOs and corporate boards are seeking multi-dimensional CIOs and IT leaders with superior skills in technology, communications, business strategy, and digital innovation. The role is more challenging than ever before\u0026lt;/em\u0026gt; — \u0026lt;em\u0026gt;but even more exciting and rewarding! \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Computer software company Adobe offers solutions for creative design and digital marketing. Most recently, DiPhillips served as CIO at Airbnb, where he led a global technology organization that modernized core business platforms, advanced AI-driven capabilities and improved productivity and cost efficiency. Prior to Airbnb, he held senior leadership roles at eBay, PayPal, Bank of America, and GE. He holds a BS from RPI Lally School of Business.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;Delta Air Lines appoints Amala Duggirala as \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Delta Air Lines is a global carrier providing domestic and international flights, and vacation packages to over 300 destinations in 60 countries. Duggirala joins Delta following her tenure as EVP and CIO at USAA, where she led enterprise-wide digital transformation initiatives. Her career includes senior tech leadership roles at Regions Bank and ACI Worldwide, with a focus on strategic modernization, cloud adoption, and customer-centric innovation. She earned a BS from Osmania University, an MS from Columbia University, and an MBA from the University of Nebraska at Omaha.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;Ahmad \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Airbnb operates an online marketplace for short- and-long-term homestays, experiences and services in various countries and regions. Al-Dahle joins from Meta, where he was VP, head of gen AI, and led gen AI and the team behind the Llama family of open-source models. Prior to Meta, he had a lengthy career at Apple.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;NCR Atleos announces Rohan Pal as CIO\u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;div class=\u0026quot;extendedBlock-wrapper block-coreImage left\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u0026lt;figure class=\u0026quot;wp-block-image alignleft size-1240-r3:2 is-resized\u0026quot;\u0026gt; width=\u0026quot;1240\u0026quot; height=\u0026quot;827\u0026quot; sizes=\u0026quot;auto, (max-width: 1240px) 100vw, 1240px\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u0026lt;figcaption class=\u0026quot;wp-element-caption\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Rohan Pal, NCR Atleos\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;/figcaption\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/figure\u0026gt;\u0026lt;p class=\u0026quot;imageCredit\u0026quot;\u0026gt;NCR Atleos\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/div\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;NCR Atleos is a provider of self-service financial solutions and ATM networks. Prior to joining, Pal served as CTO at WillScot, where he spearheaded a reimagination of the company’s technology vision. Previously, he was chief transformation officer at ServiceNow, where he worked directly with customers and boards to guide and advise their digital transformation journeys. Pal held prior roles at Brinks, Tyco, HD Supply and Home Depot. He holds a BS from Trinity University, MS degrees from St. Mary’s University and Georgia Tech, and an MBA from Dartmouth’s Tuck School of Business.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;/figcaption\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/figure\u0026gt;\u0026lt;p class=\u0026quot;imageCredit\u0026quot;\u0026gt;BioMarin\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/div\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Founded in 1997, BioMarin is a global rare disease biotechnology company focused on delivering medicines for people living with genetically defined conditions. Previously, Davé was a tech exec with Amgen, Inc. where he was responsible for the teams driving digital transformation through AI and digital technology and innovation. Prior to Amgen, Davé held leadership roles at Bristol Myers Squibb and Merck, with a focus on CIO leadership, data science and R\u0026amp;amp;D. He holds a BS from S.P. University and an MS from the University of Texas.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;University of Arizona appoints Elliott Cheu as Cheu joined in 1996 and most recently served as interim CIO. He previously served in multiple leadership positions there, including associate dean for the College of Science, interim dean of the W.A. Franke Honors College and the College of Science, associate VP for research institutes, and interim SVP for research and innovation. He earned a Ph.D. from Cornell University.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;Dave Fazio named CIO for Smith Douglas Homes\u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;RealTruck is a manufacturer and retailer of accessories for truck, Jeep, Bronco and off-road enthusiasts around the world. Most recently, Firer served as CIO for Kellanova North America (formerly Kellogg Company), where he led regional IT strategy and execution. Before that, he held senior CIO roles at Bacardi, The Estée Lauder Companies Inc., and J.Crew overseeing technology across North America, Latin America, and the Caribbean. Firer holds a BS from Binghamton University School of Management.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;Thomas Marlow joins Bayhealth has \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Bayhealth provides a wide range of medical services, including cardiovascular, cancer, orthopedics and rehabilitation, pediatrics, respiratory care, sleep care, surgical weight loss and women’s services. Marlow joins Bayhealth from University of Texas Southwestern (UTSW) Medical Center, where he served as associate VP of technology operations and Southwestern Health Resources, where he served as CIO. He earned a bachelor’s of interdisciplinary studies at Virigina Tech and an MBA from Averett University.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;The Oncology Institute announces \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Founded in 2007, The Oncology Institute specializes in cancer care with over 100 clinics and affiliate locations. Panda most recently served as VP of healthcare information services where he spearheaded the transition to cloud and AI technologies. Previously, he served as CTO and head of operations/IT for multiple high-growth startups. Panda holds a BS from the National Institute of Technology Rourkela.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;Jay Tkachuk joins Redwood Credit Union as class=\"pl-ent\"\u003edescription\u003c/span\u003e\u0026gt;\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e\u0026lt;![CDATA[\u003c/span\u003e\u0026lt;div id=\u0026quot;remove_no_follow\u0026quot;\u0026gt; \u0026lt;div class=\u0026quot;grid grid--cols-10@md grid--cols-8@lg article-column\u0026quot;\u0026gt; \u0026lt;div class=\u0026quot;col-12 col-10@md col-6@lg col-start-3@lg\u0026quot;\u0026gt; \u0026lt;div class=\u0026quot;article-column__content\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;section class=\u0026quot;wp-block-bigbite-multi-title\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u0026lt;div class=\u0026quot;container\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/div\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/section\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;A few years ago, the term AI agent was unknown to most CIOs. It only showed up in a handful of academic papers far removed from the realities of the business world. Today, AI agents are quickly becoming part of the enterprise fabric, forcing CIOs to adapt to a new model of work where humans exist alongside these autonomous systems.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;And adoption of \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://www.cio.com/article/4116514/agentic-ai-poised-for-progress-in-2026-if-cios-get-it-right.html?utm=hybrid_search\u0026quot;\u0026gt;AI agents\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt; is only accelerating. According to Dynatrace’s \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://www.dynatrace.com/info/reports/the-pulse-of-agentic-ai-in-2026/\u0026quot; rel=\u0026quot;nofollow\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Pulse of Agentic AI 2026\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt; report, 26% of organizations already have 11 or more agent projects underway. While roughly half of these initiatives remain in the POC or pilot stage, a growing number of companies have moved beyond experimentation into scaled deployment. AI agents are used primarily in IT operations and DevOps, with adoption also expanding in software engineering and customer support.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;“Most agents today are large language models augmented with access to tools, systems, or data via APIs and controlled permissions,” says Thomas Serban von Davier, AI/ML research scientist at Carnegie Mellon’s Software Engineering Institute. “Effective adoption depends less on the technology itself and more on clear governance and access strategies developed in partnership with IT teams.”\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;In other words, CIOs are expected to take on far more responsibilities in the near future. “The role is evolving from system owner to workforce orchestrator,” adds Hrishikesh Pippadipally, CIO at accounting company Wiss. “CIOs will increasingly be responsible for designing hybrid teams of humans, agents, and vendors.”\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;While this road opens up opportunities, it also comes with a complex set of challenges. And CIOs will have to be smart about when and how they use AI agents, supervise them, and how they balance autonomy with accountability as these systems take on a more active role in everyday work.​\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h2 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;when-is-a-task-a-good-fit-for-an-ai-agent\u0026quot;\u0026gt;When is a task a good fit for an AI agent?\u0026lt;/h2\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;A year ago, enthusiasm pushed organizations to try agents anywhere automation sounded interesting. But as they spread across the enterprise, CIOs have to become more strategic, focusing on the specific area where this technology can bring value.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;“The current sweet spot for agentic AI is to automate repeatable processes that span multiple systems,” says Joe Locandro, global CIO at Rimini Street. By pulling data from these sources and automating manual steps, he says, agents can streamline workflows and reduce the effort required to complete routine tasks.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;The repetitive work that requires a lot of enterprise context is where AI can shine, says Debo Dutta, CAIO at cloud computing company Nutanix. Agents, he adds, are also well suited for deeper research, where pulling together fragmented information can otherwise demand significant human effort.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;When deciding whether to use AI agents or not, it helps to have clear, upfront criteria. Pippadipally typically looks at three things. “First, the task must be well-bounded with clear inputs, outputs, and success criteria,” he says. “Then the risk profile needs to be manageable — tasks that are advisory or preparatory are better fits than those involving final decisions or regulatory accountability.” Finally, he wants to know whether the task benefits more from speed, scale, or pattern recognition than from human intuition, judgment, or relationship context. “If a task still requires frequent exceptions, nuanced stakeholder judgment, or deep domain accountability, it stays human-led with AI support rather than being fully agent-driven,” he adds.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Usually, tasks that are a good fit for AI agents tend to share a few common traits. They involve high manual effort, carry low decision risk with AI supporting rather than replacing human judgment, \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://www.cio.com/article/4121907/3-things-cost-optimized-cios-should-focus-on-to-achieve-maximum-value.html?utm=hybrid_search\u0026quot;\u0026gt;deliver value across multiple people, teams, or processes\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt;, and rely on data that’s not highly sensitive.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;By experimenting, CIOs can understand how AI works and where its strengths are. “So if a task is about doing research or exploring alternative solutions, we usually start with AI,” says Anton Vodolazkyi, CTO at software company Obrio. “If that’s not enough, we step in manually.”\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h2 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;measuring-the-productivity-of-ai-agents\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Measuring the productivity of AI agents\u0026lt;/h2\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;When assessing AI agent productivity, traditional IT metrics capture only part of the picture. Solely focusing on cost misses critical dimensions of value, such as how reliable outcomes are, and how much human capacity is freed up.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;“Instead of measuring AI agents purely on cost savings, we look at a combination of cycle-time reduction, throughput, error rates, and capacity unlocked for higher-value work,” Pippadipally says. For example, if an agent reduces a task from hours to minutes and frees up skilled staff to focus on analysis or client-facing work, and provides accurate results, that’s meaningful ROI.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Only considering speed would be a mistake, because faster outcomes mean little if agents introduce errors, amplify risk, or create downstream rework for human teams. This is why accuracy and reliability should remain central to how organizations assess agent performance.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;But \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://www.cio.com/article/4106788/ai-roi-how-to-measure-the-true-value-of-ai-2.html?utm=hybrid_search\u0026quot;\u0026gt;measuring the productivity and ROI of AI agents\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt; isn’t straightforward since they function primarily as tools that empower humans, and there’s a blurred line between what the agent contributes and what the human ultimately delivers.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;When it comes to time saved, a decent threshold would be around 50% per use case, says Max Stukalenko, head of IT at app developer MacPaw. “As these systems mature, we plan to introduce more structured metrics, including quality, adoption, and scalability indicators.”\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Oleksii Reshetniak, VP of IT and administration at software company Intellias, also cautions against declaring clear ROI too early in an AI agent project, noting that early performance can be misleading. “The first weeks are usually tuning and stabilization, so we treat early results as signal, not proof,” he says.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h2 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;main-challenges-for-cios\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Main challenges for CIOs\u0026lt;/h2\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;As with any new technology, the introduction of AI agents brings a mix of promise and complexity, adding new layers to \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://www.cio.com/article/4107216/7-changes-to-the-cio-role-in-2026.html?utm=hybrid_search\u0026quot;\u0026gt;an already demanding CIO role\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt;. CIOs have to think about governance, risk, talent, and organizational change, and at the same time, they’re being confronted with a constant stream of new AI tools that promise competitive advantage.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;“Given that technology and software are moving at such a fast pace, it’s a challenge for CIOs to select the correct platform and tools,” says Rimini Street’s Locandro. “Similarly, a lot of AI continues to be embedded in software solutions and, therefore, the challenge is to figure out what should be embedded versus custom AI.”\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;This proliferation of tools makes it harder to maintain architectural coherence and consistent oversight across the enterprise, increasing both complexity and risk. So one of the biggest challenges is to keep up with all these and decide on build vs. buy, Nutanix’ Dutta says.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Governance, accountability, and \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://www.cio.com/article/4108605/4-mandates-for-cios-to-bridge-the-ai-trust-gap.html?utm=hybrid_search\u0026quot;\u0026gt;trust\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt; are other issues that come up when CIOs are asked about the challenges of deploying and supervising AI agents. “Defining clear boundaries for what agents are allowed to do, assigning ownership for outcomes, integrating agents into legacy architectures, and managing expectations versus actual capabilities all require careful attention,” says Teymuraz Bezhashvyly, CTO at Catomize by hidden hint, a Swiss-engineered retail analytics company. “As a result, the CIO role is evolving toward stronger oversight of AI governance, risk management, and cross-functional alignment, rather than purely technology deployment.”\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Even as AI begins to reshape day-to-day work, not everyone is prepared to change how they operate, and that resistance makes a CIO’s job even harder. Therefore, driving adoption often requires as much focus on people and culture as on technology itself.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;“AI workshops, gamification approaches, and other similar activities work rather well, but it takes time and effort to change the way people do things, and encourage them to adopt these changes,” MacPaw’s Stukalenko says.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h2 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;hard-lessons-learned\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Hard lessons learned\u0026lt;/h2\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Many organizations would’ve made slightly different choices if given the chance. The earliest agent deployments were often about curiosity or speed, and fundamental questions were left out.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;“Based on our prior experience, my recommendation is to plan well, especially for the different agent types, their goals, and ways to evaluate if the agent is doing its job,” Dutta said.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;A recurring theme among CIOs is the value of starting small. Successful teams tend to introduce agents first in internal use cases, learn what works in practice, and only then expand their scope. Dutta also points to the importance of architectural flexibility. Designing enterprise systems to support multiple agent vendors, he says, helps avoid overreliance on a single provider and makes it easier to adapt as capabilities, pricing models, and \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://www.cio.com/article/4072396/coming-ai-regulations-have-it-leaders-worried-about-hefty-compliance-fines.html?utm=hybrid_search\u0026quot;\u0026gt;regulatory requirements continue to evolve\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt;.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Beyond technology choices, organizations also learned the hard way that accountability can’t be an afterthought. “Clear ownership and governance need to be established early, and \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://www.cio.com/article/3821624/workday-aims-to-manage-ai-agents-like-employees.html?utm=hybrid_search\u0026quot;\u0026gt;agents should be treated more like junior team members\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt; than autonomous replacements,” says Bezhashvyly.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Feedback loops and monitoring should also be implemented from day one, he adds, and someone must always own the final output regardless of how much work an agent has performed. That oversight is most effective when it’s shared and reviewed by the right mix of technical and business leaders.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;“Looking back, we would involve security and legal teams earlier in the process and avoid overengineering initial implementations before real usage patterns are well understood,” Bezhashvyly adds.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Others caution that the rollout of AI agents is as much a human challenge as a technical one, so having people with the right skills, judgment, and authority in place becomes critical.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;​”If we were to do it again, we’d invest earlier in \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://www.cio.com/article/1249347/8-change-management-questions-every-it-leader-must-answer.html?utm=hybrid_search\u0026quot;\u0026gt;change management\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt; and training, particularly around how managers supervise AI-driven work,” Pippadipally says. “Treating agents as part of the workforce and not just another application requires a mindset shift that’s just as important as the technology itself.”​\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;/div\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/div\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/div\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/div\u0026gt;\u003cspan class=\"pl-ent\"\u003edescription\u003c/span\u003e\u0026gt;\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e\u0026lt;![CDATA[\u003c/span\u003e\u0026lt;div id=\u0026quot;remove_no_follow\u0026quot;\u0026gt; \u0026lt;div class=\u0026quot;grid grid--cols-10@md grid--cols-8@lg article-column\u0026quot;\u0026gt; \u0026lt;div class=\u0026quot;col-12 col-10@md col-6@lg col-start-3@lg\u0026quot;\u0026gt; \u0026lt;div class=\u0026quot;article-column__content\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;section class=\u0026quot;wp-block-bigbite-multi-title\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u0026lt;div class=\u0026quot;container\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/div\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/section\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Electronic components distributor Avnet oversees supply chains for major corporations, but more importantly, the Phoenix-based multinational leverages intelligence insight from its data to help understand what’s important for customers to move product for maximum profitability.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;“Everything we do from an AI standpoint helps to fulfil that philosophy,” says \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://www.linkedin.com/in/ljchan/\u0026quot; rel=\u0026quot;nofollow\u0026quot;\u0026gt;CIO Max Chan\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt;. “Leveraging AI means \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://www.cio.com/article/4113707/when-it-comes-to-ai-not-all-data-is-created-equal.html?utm=hybrid_search\u0026quot;\u0026gt;cleansing data\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt; so customers can make the right decisions.”\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;With over 100 years of history to look back on, Avnet has always been able to prioritize technological investment as its ecosystem has grown more complex. Fundamentally important is adhering to what’s most important to the business. “Instead of having my own technology or approach to digital AI, the strategy is how do we enable the business,” he says. “So every capability we have, we look at technology, digital enablement, and AI transformation to help accelerate, redesign, or reimagine them. It’s all about helping to transform the business.”\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Of course, ROI from AI can be elusive, but Chan sees missteps or flawed strategies as evidence oflooking at the wrong place. “Some people look for ROI from an investment in AI itself,” he says. “It’s like the traditional ways of looking at FinOps, for instance, to look at how much you’re spending, improving, and making out of it. We look at it differently. To us, AI is transformational, so when we implement something with AI in mind, we look at what business outcome are we hoping to drive. We get the right pricing and a more complete quote to the customer to help them learn what that converts to in terms of top and bottom line.”\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;But just like everything else regarding technology investment or digital enablement, success comes down to \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://www.cio.com/article/221699/7-change-management-certifications-to-boost-your-it-career.html?utm=hybrid_search\u0026quot;\u0026gt;change management\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt; and governance. “Change management is key, but the overall governance of going back to whether something is contributing to a business outcome, or is directly supporting a business strategy, is essential,” he adds. “Otherwise, people will look at different POCs and use cases. We’re only looking for what directly links to strategic capabilities and the business outcome we’re looking for.”\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Chan also details modernizing legacy systems with greenfield architectures, and partnerships that build resilience and customer value across industries. Watch the full video below for more insights, and be sure to subscribe to the monthly Center Stage newsletter by clicking \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://www.cio.com/newsletters/signup/\u0026quot;\u0026gt;here\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt;.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;figure class=\u0026quot;wp-block-embed is-type-video is-provider-youtube wp-block-embed-youtube wp-embed-aspect-16-9 wp-has-aspect-ratio\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u0026lt;div class=\u0026quot;wp-block-embed__wrapper youtube-video\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;iframe loading=\u0026quot;lazy\u0026quot; title=\u0026quot;Avnet CIO Max Chan details AI-driven supply chain transformation strategy\u0026quot; width=\u0026quot;500\u0026quot; height=\u0026quot;281\u0026quot; src=\u0026quot;https://www.youtube.com/embed/d6DFG7KxSe4?start=1069\u0026amp;amp;feature=oembed\u0026quot; frameborder=\u0026quot;0\u0026quot; allow=\u0026quot;accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share\u0026quot; referrerpolicy=\u0026quot;strict-origin-when-cross-origin\u0026quot; allowfullscreen\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/iframe\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;/div\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/figure\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;How AI helps distribution: \u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt;We see very strong leverage in the sales enablement site, engineering design, managing inventory and forecasting, and orchestrating the supply chain. The common thread across all these areas is the actionable insight and data we have. So from a sales enablement perspective, what comes to mind is quoting, which is the most important thing as a distributor in terms of being informed and passing that on as quickly as we can to customers. For them, they’re able to get their products at the point they need. For us, we’re able to win the business and improve conversion. AI has helped us with pricing, getting the right information on end of life and country of origins, and putting it all together so the customer can make the best decision for what they do. It’s also about how we can help our customer service agents have readily available information to advise people. So we use it internally and externally.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;On the heavy lift of legacy systems: \u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt;This has been a long journey we’ve been on. Avnet continues to reinvent and apply the same mentality to modernize with technology. Over 30 years ago, we decided we wanted to go to a major \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://www.cio.com/article/4121113/erp-in-2026-more-ai-more-best-of-breed-add-ons.html?utm=hybrid_search\u0026quot;\u0026gt;ERP\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt; to run everything, but within the last 10 years, we realized that such a monolithic environment isn’t good enough. So we started building, just like everyone else, to get benefit from cloud transformations and build on top of it. But what my team and I quickly learned was that wasn’t going to cut it. We had support from the organization to start from scratch, and build a modern architecture that’s digital and AI first, which allows us to leverage different capabilities. The mentality of continuous improvement, and not to get hung up on what we’ve built over the last 30 years, has helped us with that success in driving AI and the transformation we see today.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;On the changes AI brings: \u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt;It comes back to \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://www.cio.com/article/4049233/5-actions-to-build-an-ai-ready-data-culture.html?utm=hybrid_search\u0026quot;\u0026gt;the culture and learning agility\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt; we want everyone in the organization to have. Interestingly, AI is probably a lot easier than most other technologies that came before it because of ChatGPT, gen AI, and the many different tools that suddenly came up in the last few years. Everyone got excited. Trying to create that learning pathway, and getting people systematically upskilled to be able to approach and leverage AI the right way, is what we’re doing across the organization. We see it like there are three different types of AI to grapple with. One is productivity tools like ChatGPT that we give people to do what they need to do. The second is what comes with all the software you have, since all major software comes with AI components. Then last are the things my team would develop and build in accordance with what we want in order to drive the company forward, and how we transform. So we have more than enough tools that we allow the organization to leverage, and we have a governance process to request what people can use, or we give them an alternative. If it comes with the software we own, if we already have the license, then go for it since it’s embedded and will help us better leverage the software. The focus we have on AI is what we’re doing to transform the way we work, the workforce, the work itself, and in some cases, the business and how we can better serve our customers and employees. One way is reimagining some end-to-end processes to see if they can be fully autonomous. If so, what would it look like? Once that’s done, we bring people back in the loop to augment it and make it even more powerful for our business.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;On AI impacting workflows: \u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt;As far as disruption and resiliency from a supply chain standpoint, focus is on relationships with customers, both upstream and downstream, and understanding what they are, what they have, what they need to do, and what they want to do. And the signals we send around the industry help strengthen that resiliency. We get asked how can we help avoid the next supply chain debacle, and it comes down to partnerships, availability of data, and connectivity. In order for us to do that internally, from a tech stack standpoint, we need to target the modern architecture that drives microservices and allows us to have \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://www.cio.com/article/4018578/why-cios-see-apis-as-vital-for-agentic-ai-success.html?utm=hybrid_search\u0026quot;\u0026gt;strong API connections\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt;. We created a platform called the Partner Digital Exchange, which helps bring data downstream, and combines it with what we have to drive orchestration. And that allows us to bring AI into the mix and help customers with the information they need. It also helps Avnet create that stickiness in the ecosystem.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;/div\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/div\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/div\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/div\u0026gt;\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e]]\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u0026lt;/\u003cspan class=\"pl-ent\"\u003edescription\u003c/span\u003e\u0026gt;"," \u0026lt;\u003cspan class=\"pl-ent\"\u003edescription\u003c/span\u003e\u0026gt;\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e\u0026lt;![CDATA[\u003c/span\u003e\u0026lt;div id=\u0026quot;remove_no_follow\u0026quot;\u0026gt; \u0026lt;div class=\u0026quot;grid grid--cols-10@md grid--cols-8@lg article-column\u0026quot;\u0026gt; \u0026lt;div class=\u0026quot;col-12 col-10@md col-6@lg col-start-3@lg\u0026quot;\u0026gt; \u0026lt;div class=\u0026quot;article-column__content\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;section class=\u0026quot;wp-block-bigbite-multi-title\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u0026lt;div class=\u0026quot;container\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/div\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/section\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Uncertainty is an integral aspect of business operations. Conventional business intelligence tools can be helpful for historical data reporting, but fail to anticipate future risks and opportunities with accuracy. To develop more effective business and financial strategies, enterprises employ predictive and prescriptive analytics.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Predictive analytics involves the use of statistical modeling and machine learning techniques to forecast potential outcomes, while prescriptive analytics recommends optimal courses of action that can enhance business revenue. However, the absence or limited cross-functional integration hinders the businesses from fully utilizing the perks of these two analytics techniques.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;AI agents can play a critical role in overcoming the challenges associated with predictive and prescriptive analytics. This article explains in detail how AI agents can improve predictive and prescriptive analytics by presenting an architectural framework that is not only efficient but also ensures data security and regulatory compliance.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h2 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;predictive-analytics-vs-prescriptive-analytics\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Predictive analytics vs prescriptive analytics\u0026lt;/h2\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;\u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://dzone.com/articles/the-difference-between-predictive-analytics-and-da\u0026quot; rel=\u0026quot;nofollow\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Predictive analytics\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt; is a data analysis technique that helps find correlations between data points and understand business trends beforehand. Historically, statistical models, including regression models such as linear and logistic regression, along with \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://www.tigerdata.com/blog/what-is-time-series-forecasting\u0026quot; rel=\u0026quot;nofollow\u0026quot;\u0026gt;time-series forecasting\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt; models like autoregressive integrated moving average (ARIMA), were used for predictive analytics.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;At present, machine learning models such as decision trees, random forests, and gradient boosting machines aid in performing predictive analytics in large-scale enterprises. On the other hand, prescriptive analytics is useful for deciding what action to take based on the results obtained by predictive analytics.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;The prescriptive analysis assists in developing strategies to optimize operations, increase profitability, and reduce risks. Traditionally, linear and non-linear programming models are used for resource allocation, supply chain management, and portfolio optimization.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Nowadays, reinforcement learning (RL) has become a popular technique for prescriptive analysis. It involves the usage of a trial-and-error approach wherein the machine learning models take feedback from each output and improve their outcomes continuously. Adaptive medical treatment and dynamic pricing in the retail sector are the most common applications of reinforcement learning.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;In enterprise decision-making, both predictive and prescriptive analytics play an important role. Predictive analytics enables forecasting possible business outcomes, while prescriptive analytics uses these forecasts to create a strategy to maximize business profits. However, enterprises often fail to integrate these two analytics techniques in an effective way for their own benefit. The data science teams generate predictive forecasts while finance or operations teams make end-point decisions, creating a gap. It is critical for businesses to pay attention to leveraging both predictive and prescriptive analytics in a unified way.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h2 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;the-rise-of-ai-agents-in-analytics-and-the-challenges-that-come-with-it\u0026quot;\u0026gt;The rise of AI agents in analytics — and the challenges that come with it\u0026lt;/h2\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;AI agents are autonomous GenAI-powered systems that can perform a set of assigned tasks by designing their own workflow. They observe their environment and figure out the best possible way to attain desired objectives. In analytics, AI agents help with data ingestion, exploration, pattern recognition, and insight generation. These systems are highly helpful for context-aware and dynamic analytics. As a result, you can use AI agents for predictive and prescriptive analytics at the enterprise level.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;However, there are certain challenges associated with the use of AI agents in data analytics. Long-term memory management, explainability, and data security are some of the factors that need to be taken care of while utilizing AI agents in your data-driven workflows. In order to do this, there is a need for a robust AI agentic framework that can help in overcoming challenges associated with predictive and prescriptive analytics.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h2 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;using-ai-agents-for-predictive-and-prescriptive-analytics-a-conceptual-framework-and-architectural-overview\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Using AI agents for predictive and prescriptive analytics: A conceptual framework and architectural overview\u0026lt;/h2\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;The integration of AI agents in predictive and prescriptive analytics workflows has not been explored much by data science professionals. However, a consolidated \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://www.ibm.com/think/insights/top-ai-agent-frameworks\u0026quot; rel=\u0026quot;nofollow\u0026quot;\u0026gt;AI agentic framework\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt; can be developed that makes integrated use of predictive and prescriptive analytics in a combined way. Here is a visual of such a framework that is easy to adapt for businesses:\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;div class=\u0026quot;extendedBlock-wrapper block-coreImage undefined\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u0026lt;figure class=\u0026quot;wp-block-image size-large\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u0026lt;img loading=\u0026quot;lazy\u0026quot; decoding=\u0026quot;async\u0026quot; src=\u0026quot;https://b2b-contenthub.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/consolidated-ai-agentic-framework.png?w=1024\u0026quot; alt=\u0026quot;Consolidated AI agentic framework\u0026quot; class=\u0026quot;wp-image-4130186\u0026quot; srcset=\u0026quot;https://b2b-contenthub.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/consolidated-ai-agentic-framework.png?quality=50\u0026amp;amp;strip=all 1200w, https://b2b-contenthub.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/consolidated-ai-agentic-framework.png?resize=300%2C70\u0026amp;amp;quality=50\u0026amp;amp;strip=all 300w, https://b2b-contenthub.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/consolidated-ai-agentic-framework.png?resize=768%2C179\u0026amp;amp;quality=50\u0026amp;amp;strip=all 768w, https://b2b-contenthub.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/consolidated-ai-agentic-framework.png?resize=1024%2C238\u0026amp;amp;quality=50\u0026amp;amp;strip=all 1024w, https://b2b-contenthub.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/consolidated-ai-agentic-framework.png?resize=150%2C35\u0026amp;amp;quality=50\u0026amp;amp;strip=all 150w, https://b2b-contenthub.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/consolidated-ai-agentic-framework.png?resize=854%2C199\u0026amp;amp;quality=50\u0026amp;amp;strip=all 854w, https://b2b-contenthub.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/consolidated-ai-agentic-framework.png?resize=640%2C149\u0026amp;amp;quality=50\u0026amp;amp;strip=all 640w, https://b2b-contenthub.com/wp-content/uploads/2026/02/consolidated-ai-agentic-framework.png?resize=444%2C103\u0026amp;amp;quality=50\u0026amp;amp;strip=all 444w\u0026quot; width=\u0026quot;1024\u0026quot; height=\u0026quot;238\u0026quot; sizes=\u0026quot;auto, (max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px\u0026quot; /\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/figure\u0026gt;\u0026lt;p class=\u0026quot;imageCredit\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Naveen Kolli\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt;\u0026lt;/div\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;Let’s look at each architectural layer one-by-one:\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;ul class=\u0026quot;wp-block-list\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;li\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;Perception layer\u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt;: This is the first layer where data ingestion and pre-processing are carried out. You can ingest data from various sources, including enterprise resource planning, customer relationship management (CRM), supply chain management, and human resource platforms. After extraction, data can be migrated using APIs, middleware connectors, or by building ETL/ELT pipelines.\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;Predictive layer\u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt;: This layer comprises tools and software to perform predictive analytics. This includes advanced AI/ML models such as gradient boosting machine, as well as deep learning models like \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://arxiv.org/abs/1909.09586\u0026quot; rel=\u0026quot;nofollow\u0026quot;\u0026gt;LSTMs\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt;. The outcomes of predictive analytics are used as input for prescriptive analytics, combining both the analysis techniques for business improvements.\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;Prescriptive layer\u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt;: Taking outputs of predictive analytics as inputs, this layer leverages simulation models and reinforcement learning to deliver prescriptive results. Due to the use of RL-based models, the prescriptive layer is highly resilient against dynamic business conditions.\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;Agent control layer\u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt;: This layer is critical for multi-agent coordination and policy compliance. You can use a domain-specific agentic framework for different sectors such as healthcare, finance, e-commerce, or HR. To comply with regulatory guidelines of GDPR, HIPAA, or industry-specific standards, you can implement policy-as-code frameworks in the agent control layer.\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;Action layer\u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt;: Lastly, the action layer is the final layer where the results generated through analytics are integrated into business decision-making. The consolidated outputs can be in the form of decision-support dashboards or real-time alerts. For instance, an agent may flag supply chain disruption as well as trigger an automated procurement adjustment workflow.\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;/ul\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h2 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;additional-aspects-critical-for-ai-powered-predictive-and-prescriptive-analytics\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Additional aspects critical for AI-powered predictive and prescriptive analytics\u0026lt;/h2\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h3 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;adaptive-memory-mechanism\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Adaptive memory mechanism\u0026lt;/h3\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;The adaptive memory mechanism forms an important component of AI agentic analytics. It aids in retaining and retrieving knowledge just like human cognition. Here are three types of adaptive memory structures:\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;ul class=\u0026quot;wp-block-list\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;li\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;Episodic memory\u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt;: This type of memory helps in recalling past events and case-specific experiences. Using episodic memory, AI-based finance agents can refer to previous instances of market downfall and the strategies that were used to overcome the situation.\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;Semantic memory\u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt;: The semantic memory is useful for storing domain-specific knowledge, such as finance, healthcare, or e-commerce. Through semantic memory, the AI agentic framework supports explainability and provides domain-specific prescriptions.\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;Working memory\u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt;: Working memory is critical for extracting instantaneous task-related information. For example, working memory gives information about current stock prices and market updates in the finance sector.\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;/ul\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h3 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;retrieval-mechanisms-for-better-decision-making\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Retrieval mechanisms for better decision-making\u0026lt;/h3\u0026gt; \u0026lt;ul class=\u0026quot;wp-block-list\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;li\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;Embedding-based search: \u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt;Unstructured data is stored as vector embeddings in \u0026lt;a href=\u0026quot;https://dzone.com/refcardz/getting-started-with-vector-databases\u0026quot; rel=\u0026quot;nofollow\u0026quot;\u0026gt;vector databases\u0026lt;/a\u0026gt;. These vector databases can be integrated with AI agents to enable embedding-based data retrieval. Such integration helps produce contextually and semantically correct predictive and prescriptive results.\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;Retrieval augmented generation (RAG): \u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt;The RAG mechanism comprises information retrieval from generative AI models or LLMs. For instance, you are building an AI agent that must prescribe actions after predicting supply delays. In such a scenario, the RAG mechanism enables the retrieval of the occurrence of past disruption events with respect to the same supplier. It can also help in finding data such as contract terms, including penalty clauses, and details of other suppliers that provide the same product.\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;Graph-based reasoning: \u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt;Graph-based reasoning involves the usage of knowledge graphs that illustrate relations between various entities, including objects, events, or situations. Such a type of retrieval mechanism is imperative for multi-hop reasoning. This facilitates the retrieval of data from multiple sources, documents, or knowledge bases.\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;/ul\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;In addition to the use of predictive and prescriptive models along with an AI agentic framework, we use evaluation metrics such as root mean squared error (RMSE) and mean absolute error (MAE). The integrated architecture utilizes AI agent toolkits such as LangChain, FAISS, and LLMs like GPT.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;In addition, there is also a requirement for cloud-based AI platforms such as Azure AI, AWS SageMaker, and Google Cloud Vertex AI. To ensure trustworthiness, the framework also involves data governance and compliance risk mitigation measures.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h2 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot; id=\u0026quot;vertical-industry-impact\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Vertical industry impact\u0026lt;/h2\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;To understand how efficient AI is in predictive and prescriptive analytics, case studies were conducted across various verticals. Let’s have a brief look at some of them:\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;ul class=\u0026quot;wp-block-list\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;li\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;Finance\u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt;: Using AI agents, we can ingest financial transaction data, credit details, and external macroeconomic indicators to predict loan defaults. Reinforcement learning proves to be of help in generating recommendations for adjusting lending strategies. It is found that such a framework can help in reducing loan default risk by 25%.\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;/ul\u0026gt; \u0026lt;ul class=\u0026quot;wp-block-list\u0026quot;\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;li\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;Healthcare\u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt;: An AI agentic framework for predictive and prescriptive analytics can aid in understanding patient readmission probabilities. Based on this information, healthcare institutions can make arrangements, including infrastructure, beds, medical equipment, and other such resources in advance. LSTM and transformer-based architectures can analyze patient health records and diagnostic histories for predicting readmission probabilities. Prescriptive agents then generate care optimization pathways, medication adjustments, and personalized treatment programs. Using the agentic framework for patient readmission improved readmission prediction by 30% and reduced overall care costs by 20%.\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt; \u0026lt;li\u0026gt;\u0026lt;strong\u0026gt;Supply chain\u0026lt;/strong\u0026gt;: The challenges of demand variation and logistic uncertainty can be resolved using an AI agentic framework in predictive and prescriptive analytics of supply chain data. To study this, predictive models were used to analyze IoT sensors, sales, and supply contract data. Moreover, prescriptive models such as MILP solvers and Q-learning help in making logistical decisions, including inventory management and shipping route selection. This practice led to 35% reduction in stockouts and 15% reduction in logistics costs.\u0026lt;/li\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e","\u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u0026lt;/ul\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;On implementing the AI agentic framework, the industries experienced better forecasts through efficient predictive analytics. On the other hand, prescriptive analytics helped businesses in making their workflows more adaptable. Despite this success, high computational costs and explainability still remain a major challenge.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;To overcome these setbacks, an enterprise can further invest in developing multi-modal predictive-prescriptive AI agents and neuro-symbolic agents. These agents use statistical models and symbolic learning for better explainability and compliance.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt; \u0026lt;h2 class=\u0026quot;wp-block-heading\u0026quot;\u0026gt;Conclusion\u0026lt;/h2\u0026gt; \u0026lt;p\u0026gt;AI agent-driven predictive and prescriptive analytics can transform enterprise workflows by enabling proactive decision-making. By introducing AI in daily operations, there can be an improvement in decision-making quality under uncertainty and a reduction in operational friction. Sectors such as finance, healthcare, retail, and e-commerce can easily include AI-powered predictive and prescriptive analytics for better business outcomes.\u0026lt;/p\u0026gt;
